Ernaux Season. Day 15. Final day.  A Chekhov quote at the beginning of the book. It sets the mood for the rest of the journey:   Yes. They’ll forget us. Such is our fate, there is no help for it. What seems to us serious, significant, very important, will one day be forgotten or will seem unimportant. And it’s curious that we can’t possibly tell what exactly will be considered great and important, and what will seem petty and ridiculous [...]. And it may be that our present life, which we accept so readily, will in time seem strange, inconvenient, stupid, not clean enough, perhaps even sinful…   Ernaux’s best work, I believe. Poetic (and nothing short of a coincidence) that I finish with this. You could read this and have a sense of everything that she is about, or you could come to it at the end of a period of bingeing her works and be able to identify every single sentence for a broader story, explored elsewhere. Alison Strayer asks in her translator’s note: “Is this Ernaux’s Remembrance of Things Past, or her Gone with the Wind, Life and Fate, with perhaps a nod to Virginia Woolf: the stream of consciousness, the struggle with the “I”...?” Yes, pretty damn close. I spent a long time with Ernaux’s words, which are contained in a world of not-quite-memoir, not-quite-fiction, not-quite-sociology, not-quite-kama-sutra. Throughout this time, I felt like I came to know her, appreciating what it is to dedicate a life to writing. I got a sense of what it means to give freely of yourself, putting it all down, attempting to reach a broad audience and a later generation through capturing the minutiae of the mundane. I let the commonplace themes wash over me, again and again. Every corner I turned brought me face to face with a familiar image: Ernaux’s struggle with class, initially refusing to accept that she could be the daughter of two people who owned and operated a café-grocery; her poor treatment of these parents in her own mind, but the poor treatment of her by her parents; a flight into purely physical, sexual fancies, still draped in Romanticism, all to escape class and parents; the war in Algeria; her periods; her abortion; her affairs. Ultimately, for her, it all culminated in a strong, overwhelming desire to belong. To achieve a certain status as a person, then to be.  I read lots of pieces from all over the place in the wake of Ernaux’s Nobel prize win, taking notes throughout exploring. Call it laziness, call it a knack for curation, but they give it all a sense of legitimacy and do her works a lot more justice than I could. Here are some of the best tidbits from what I read.  Dwight Garner’s piece in the NYT likened Ernaux to someone else that I am reading at the moment, which made me happy: “Like the poet Louise Glück, who won the Nobel in 2020, hers is a voice of rough compassion. Each looks out levelly at the world; each derives maximum effect from a minimum of words.” He also referred to her “direct” style: “Ernaux has characterized her language as “brutally direct, working-class and sometimes obscene.” She has an antagonism toward what she has called “the French tradition of the polished sentence, of ‘good taste’ in literature.”” I sat up and took note of something I hadn’t noticed without having had it sketched out for me: “You sense her influence in the austere, astringent work of many so-called autofiction writers, notably Rachel Cusk and Sheila Heti.” Yep. No wonder I took a liking to her.  I always love hearing what Sam Sacks has to say when he puts out his weekly reviews on the WSJ website. He calls Ernaux an “heir to Proust”, saying that “Ms. Ernaux, in contrast, casts a colder eye on her life and background, utilizing the clinical tools of, in her words, “attention to detail, use of a descriptive past tense, analysis of events.”” He mentions that “her books confront the deaths of her parents, her earliest sexual experience, her abortion at the age of 23 and her midlife love affair with a boorish younger man - subjects of supercharged emotion that she presents with studied distance and hard-earned objectivity.” Yet, in a way, Sam disagrees with Dwight Garner’s comparison of Ernaux to Cusk and Heti, at least a tiny bit: “The rigor and refinement of her method means that care must be taken with the claim that her victory also serves to valorize the popular current trend of autofiction. Ms. Ernaux’s books are made of sterner stuff than most contemporary memoir-novel hybrids, which typically stress the “otherness” of the author, bring to the surface some repressed trauma, and function in a way not dissimilar to therapy sessions. But Ms. Ernaux’s writing is not confessional as much as documentary. Writing as “an ethnologist of myself,” as she put it, she has been able to endow private experience with wider significance, creating the uncanny sense among her readers - until now, a small but fervent circle - that she has spoken for them, too. The “I” in her books is a setting as well as a person, a physical place - in this case a woman’s body - where events of psychological, social and political consequence occur.”  Sheila Heti herself jumps into the mix, writing a guest spot for the NYT. As I mentioned, Ernaux’s writing is dripping with class consciousness - as Heti puts it, “Ms. Ernaux has written that her aversion to playing with metaphors comes from an allegiance to her parents. She doesn’t want to write in a way that is different from how the people she grew up with speak.” In The Years, “the main character is no longer her or her family but time itself… Ms. Ernaux presents time as something onto which, if just for a moment, the detritus of civilization attaches; it favors no one thing over anything else. Time leaves behind world wars as lightly as it leaves behind the greatest movie stars, sexual mores, one’s parents, grandparents, children.” [Also, Alan interjects here to say: Sheila! What the fuck! Don’t change the spelling just because you’re writing for NYT. Say it loud and proud and Torontonian: F A V O U R] “The beautiful form of The Years is utterly its own, and I find it hard to think of a book more moving. She shows that humans are not their insides but their props and their settings. It is reassuring to imagine the self or the soul as something eternal, but it is harder to think that of a can of peas. It is a resolute - yet somehow euphoric - book about mortality, about how everything is always being lost to time, often without our even noticing it.”  Perhaps the best place to start for those are curious about Ernaux (and for some reason) don’t want to jump into primary material) is Alexandra Schwartz’s article for The New Yorker, in the November 21st issue, published online as Annie Ernaux Turns Memory Into Art. A quick glance at the books, a quick history lesson, a discussion with Ernaux herself. She mentions “in the course of her nearly fifty-year career, Ernaux has published more than twenty books. The first few were what you and I would call autobiographical novels: the protagonists, young women to whom Ernaux lent her own thoughts and experiences, are clearly self-portraits. Pretty soon, though, Ernaux pulled down the scrim of fiction and adopted the first person. Her “I” is not a put-on, some coy invitation to the reader to try to untangle what is real from what is false. Ernaux works exclusively from the factual material of life - her life.”  And as I have mentioned countless times now, this excavation of her own life leaves the reader a plethora of lasting memories and images. For me, another image from The New Yorker, illustrated by Sébastien Plassard. Its impact has remained - a final image of mother in her home, seared into the brain, residing in a place of calm, peace, nostalgia - the meadows of melancholy memory.      Quotes:  “We discovered the joys of order. Our melancholy at seeing a personal project fade into the distance – painting, writing, or making music – was compensated by the satisfaction of contributing to the family project.”  “At every moment in time, next to the things it seems natural to do and say, and next to the ones we’re told to think – no less by books or ads in the Métro than by funny stories – are other things that society hushes up without knowing it is doing so. Thus it condemns to lonely suffering all the people who feel but cannot name these things. Then the silence breaks, little by little, or suddenly one day, and words burst forth, recognized at last, while underneath other silences start to form.”  “Her main concern is the choice between “I” and “she.” There is something too permanent about “I,” something shrunken and stifling, whereas “she” is too exterior and remote. The image she has of her book in its nonexistent form, of the impression it should leave, is the one she retained from Gone with the Wind, read at the age of twelve, and later from Remembrance of Things Past, and more recently from Life and Fate: an image of light and shadow streaming over faces. But she hasn’t yet discovered how to do this. She awaits if not a revelation then a sign, a happenstance, as the madeleine dipped in tea was for Marcel Proust.”  “And we did not age. The things around us didn’t last long enough to grow old, replaced and rehabilitated at lightning speed. Our memory didn’t have time to associate them with moments of existence.”  “By retrieving the memory of collective memory in an individual memory, she will capture the lived dimension of History.”  “This will not be a work of remembrance in the usual sense, aimed at putting life into story, creating an explanation of self. She will go within herself only to retrieve the world, the memory and imagination of its bygone days, grasp the changes in ideas, beliefs, and sensibility, the transformation of people and the subject that she has seen – perhaps nothing compared to those her granddaughter will see, as will all beings who are alive in 2070. To hunt down sensations that are already there, as yet unarmed, such as the one that is making her write.”

What does a long life mean today? Looking back on a long life, what do our memories say about these times, our communities, our ideas, our choices? This powerful book is thought-provoking even if we can’t understand the signifiers of pop culture and politics in France. Can’t wait to read more from this talented author.

I began Les Années more enthralled than I thought I would be. By the halfway mark, though, I found myself bored and annoyed by turns and left with little desire to read to the end. I found Ernaux's reflections on ageing and the sudden passage of time quite touching, how words like 'quarante' or 'retraite' suddenly appear and catch us off guard. In this respect I thought the book well crafted, as if it had managed to simulate how our memories work. I enjoyed some of the societal critique - especially about phones, hypermarkets and sprawling and soulless suburban development - but much of it felt so unoriginal and obvious, and at times the novel turns into a predictable and worn-out catalogue of right-thinking idées reçues and clichéd events.  Not that there is anything wrong with this per se, but it was dispiriting to watch Ernaux's political concerns - rather like her life itself - drift along in a state of vapid indifference and ghostlike nothingness. Perhaps our heroine's indifference to all that life has thrown at at her is entirely the point of this self-proclaimed new type of autobiography, but I struggled to feel anything for her at all. And what about all of the other characters? She might mention again and again how much she wanted to write like Proust, but at least he created a world populated by the thoughts and feelings of the people that surround his narrator: in The Years, Ernaux's family are even more insubstantial than herself. I'm left far more excited to read a tell-all memoir from her ex-husband than any of her other books...  I recently watched an interview with Ernaux in which she claimed her detractors are just those that haven't read her. Well, at least now I can claim to no longer be among their number. The book would be a good introduction to the major social changes and historical events of the last several decades and of one woman's life within them, but it's hard to get quite so excited when we know all of these things already. Perhaps her imaginary reader from 2070 will be more kind.

Although this is a translation it is still an excellent read. However, stick with it and you will understand why Annie Ernaux was awarded the Nobel Prize this year. This is my first book to read of hers and it will not be the last. I am Irish and we have James Joyce and Ulysses - the French now have their own equivalent. Treat the book kindly and it will reward you.

Excellent.  Annie Ernaux is only 19 years older than I, so the memories she lays down about events are contemporaneous to my memories. The measured, non-author'd fiction of her life and the world's events are non-climatic, normal. Structured only by time. Events happen and other events move us on. Beautiful presentation of a life. A presentation that we can learn from.  Edited, authored, fiction chooses specific messages to leave us with; presented toward a climax that makes a point. That is not how life occurs.  A major attraction for me was the point of view is female, and French. Neither of these two POVs do I run across often. Unhidden, unashamedly, different. When I read, especially literature in translation, this is what I want - a different point of view. I can relive my own memories at will; living someone else's, whether as a memoir or as fiction, is exciting.  Now that she has the Nobel Prize, much has been written about her and her approach (better than I can).

There seems to be a collection of books about women that has run parallel to my life. This is the one for a time of change, becoming, and navigating the next steps of adulthood. It is profoundly wise, but a challenging work of art, best swallowed, sat with during long stretches of time, until my feet get sore from sitting cross-legged and the words, images, and the phrases make up every nerve and movement of my fingers. If there is one reason to learn French it is to read this book how Ernaux wrote it. The structure is so important to how the novel carries weight, a motion of its own. To read it in translation cheapened the effect, I am sure, no matter the diligence of the translators. About the structure—it had its own internal mimesis, self-referential because the praxis of writing is something Ernaux tags to the essence of her French culture. I love how she would mention that she wanted to write this very thing we are holding as readers, but it is nestled in the folds of pages describing her life thirty years prior to when it was published. There is a diligence to her that feels very hopeful, for we so often saw things that we never get around to doing. The Years is an antidote to solipsistic narcissism, and it made me finally understand why Virginia Woolf is so against the individual writing about themselves in their novels. Annie Ernaux achieved the impossible here! Capturing the essence of generations, skimming the froth of politics, culture, how a child grows their limp flesh to the muscle of adolescence, it is all contained like a sprinting figure which the brain perceives in short frames, clear blots and images and then a blur of years pass in front of our eyes. It is a magical experience to read these journalistic-in-tone, poetry-in-construction paragraphs (albeit some poorly constructed sentences that may be because of the translation). The most gripping paragraph that I've read in all of literature recently was about the formation of silent undercurrents in public discourse isolating individuals who feel it, and when it comes to fruition it is worked through by the people while new silences grow. In all our discussions about societal failings, mental health, etc. etc. on social media, where it is easy to be seen for our shared humanity and shared traumas, I am comforted to know that it never really satisfies the need to be understood. What an abstraction to put so deftly—I am deeply impressed.  I declare, in the midst of learning languages, that the reason I learn French is for Ernaux.

review": This is a powerful memoir that takes us beyond one person's existential overindulgent angst (which is what most memoirs are) and meta-analyzes her past for all to consider. really excellent  “Of all the ways in which self-knowledge may be fos- tered, perhaps one of the greatest is a person's ability to discern how they view the past, at every time of life and every age; if that is so, what kind of memory can be ascribed to this girl in the second row? Maybe she has no memory except that of the previous summer, almost bereft of images - the incorporation of a missing body, a man's. Two future goals coexist inside her: (1) to be thin and blonde, (2) to be free, autonomous, and useful to the world. She dreams of herself as Mylène Demongeot and Simone de Beauvoir.”  “No sign of the heaviness of existence she must tear herself away from to master the language of philos- ophy, serve the injunction of essence and the categorical imperative, subjugate the body, repress the desire for food and the obsession with the monthly blood that no longer flows. Reflect on the real so it will cease to be real, become an abstract thing - intangible, a product of intelligence. A few weeks later, she will stop eating, buy Néo-Antigrès fat-burning pills, and be reduced to pure consciousness. After class, when she walks up boulevard du Marne, past the funfair booths, the howl of the music follows her like calamity.”  “She ofien revisits images of herself single, in the streets of cities where she has walked and in the rooms she has occupied -in a young ladies' hostel in Rouen, in Finchley as an au pair or a penzione on via Servio Tullio, on holiday in Rome. These are her selves, it seems to her, who continue to exist in these places. In other words, past and future are reversed. The obiect of desire is not the future but the past; she desires to be back in the room in Rome, in the summer of 1963. In her journal she writes: 'Out of extreme narcissism, I want to see my past set down on paper and in that way, be as I am not' and ‘There's a certain image of women that torments me. ‘“  “In those rooms, she never sees herself with the clarity of photos, but blurred as in a film on an encrypted TV channel. Or she sees a silhouette, a hair-stvle, movements - leaning out of a window, washing her hair - and positions - sitting at a desk or lying on a bed. Sometimes she manages to feel she is back inside her former body, not the way one is in dreams, but more as if she were inside the glorious body' of the Catholic religion, which was supposed to resurrect after death with no sensation of pain or pleasure, heat, cold, or the urge to urinate. She doesn't know what she wants from these inventories, except maybe through the accumulation of memories of objects, to again become the person she was at such and such a time. She would like to assemble these multiple images of herself, separate and discordant, thread them together with the story of her existence, starting with her birth during World War II up until the present day. Therefore, an existence that is singular but also merged with the movements of a generation.”  “There was no ineffable world that leapt out from inspired words, as if by magic, and she would never write except from inside her language, which is everyone's language, the only tool she's ever intended on using to act upon the things that outraged her. So the book to be written represented an instrument of struggle. She hasn't abandoned this ambition, but now, more than anything, she would like to capture the light that suffuses faces that can no longer be seen and tables groaning with vanished food, the light that was already present in the stories of Sundays in childhood and has continued to settle upon things from the moment they are lived, a light from before. To save  the little village fête at Bazoches-sur-Hoène with the bumper cars  the hotel room on the rue Beauvoisine in Rouen, not far from the Lepouzé bookshop, where Cayatte filmed a scene for To Die of Love  the wine tap at the Carrefour on rue du Parmelan, Annecy  I leaned against the beauty of the world I And I held the smell of the seasons in my hands  the merry-go-round at the spa park in Saint-Honoré-les Bains  the very young woman in a red coat walking down the pavement next to a staggering man she had gone to fetch at the Café Le Duguesclin, in the winter, in La Roche-Posay…”

A hybrid book, a historic book, a biography, a documentary, a chronicle, all these can be seen in each page of the book! And it really doesn't matter what you consider it as the book doesn't claim any of these. It is a unique writing and the only thing it claims is its uniqueness. Ernaux is multi disciplinary, versatile author. She is writing, like in poetry, her thoughts before rationalization. The effect of this is that you feel the events and the periods that she is describing rather than reading an account or description of the period. You mostly feel the period rather than learning about the period. At the end you have an honest engagement in a period of time you may have not lived because is before you while the repercussions of that period affected you, or, and this is a guess, if you have lived during that time and in those places, it offers you an alternative understanding of what was happening around you. In each case you are a witness of a unique human account of the history of human beings.

Wow. Tells the story of a generation of women by telling one woman’s story, from growing up as a baby boomer in the shadow of WW2, to the enlightenment of the 1960s, everything that once was taboo becoming acceptable, progress and commercialism. The style is detached yet intimate, told through photos and images that evoke memories. Unlike anything I’ve ever read before.

If you're interested in history or just want to get a sense of how society has evolved over the years, then this book is definitely worth a read. Just be prepared for a slow and introspective journey through the banalities of life.  The Years is a unique and thought-provoking book that follows one woman's journey through life as she navigates the ups and downs of everyday experiences.  On the one hand, Ernaux's writing is vivid and detailed, bringing the mundane aspects of life to life in a way that is truly captivating. Whether it's grocery shopping or family dinner, she manages to infuse even the most ordinary events with a sense of wonder and introspection. On the other hand, some readers may find the slow pace and focus on everyday events to be tedious and uninteresting.  However, it's important to note that The Years is not just a simple tale of one woman's life. It's also a rich and enlightening exploration of how society has changed over the course of several decades, from the end of World War II to the year 2000. Ernaux masterfully weaves together her own personal experiences with the larger historical events of the time, giving readers a unique and intimate look at how these events have impacted our world.  On a side note, I like how this quotation speaks to the sense of change and transformation that is often associated with youth, and the feeling of stagnation and immobility that can come with age:  Unlike her teenage years when she was certain that she was not the same from one year

review": A book with a big reputation, but which I found somewhat flat perhaps because it requires such a detailed knowledge of French popular culture and post-war political life, a lot of which went over my head. I think, too, that the much vaunted stylistic innovation of this work should perhaps be considered in relation to, say, Joan Didion. And, let us add, at least one other, Murray Bail (he. 2021), have done it better since. Still, with its fragmented memory anchored on photographs The Years has its moments and manages “to save something from the time where we will never be again.”

Lovely. The collective judgements mostly feel representational and accurate and fair, even to this reader, born of a different generation and never a French citizen. The reflections on capitalism and consumer culture are highlights, as are those on sex/pleasure/desire. Enjoyable and engaging throughout. Although I never really felt awed by the depth of insight or creativity or any other particular literary achievement. As pleasingly melancholy as an early Leonard Cohen song.

This is a most remarkable piece of writing. It is not a novel, it is not an autobiography. To use the author’s words it is “By retrieving the memory of collective memory in an individual memory, she will capture the lived dimension of History.”  “To save something from the time where we will never be again.” Read it.

This book follows the trajectory of my life, just a few years later in its beginnings and on another continent. Poignant yet deeply perceptive of the past and what it brings to the present, or not. I would appreciate reading this alongside someone fluent in French to assist with untranslated terminology and titles.

I cannot sufficiently recommend this masterful book. It is really a before-and-after event for me. The story of the author is the story of France is the story of the postwar period in Europe. Though the emphasis seems detached and sociological, it also feels very intimate and personal. What a wonderful way to tell a story!  There are loads of references to people, events, etc. which may make it difficult to read. My knowledge of post-war French politics is not too bad, but even with half the references missing it is not really an obstacle to a growing fascination with the accounts, and as they become more contemporary, and therefore more familiar, they also do not loose their poignancy, their critical sharpness and richness.  And so, even if you don´t know much about contemporary French history, you must read this book.
This is a beautifully written book.

Annie Ernaux's classic pulls off what in a logline sounds impossible: a memoir that fuses one woman's life with the collective memory of a French generation. She does this with highly specific details that speak to a whole milieu, and the translation loses none of her exquisitely poetic writing. I enjoyed its lens into the societal transformations within just a lifetime, most notably the country's leap from Catholic conservatism to the liberal attitudes it is now known for, and how they charted the author's own course from a married mother to an author with lovers and adult children.  This premise inherently assumes some extent of shared perspective, and toward the end I felt a little irritated by some of the sweeping political generalizations, especially since they are fairly predictable ones.

review": An emotional history of the modern world

In many ways quite a simple book, but I really liked it - a sort of social history of people's experiences and emotions in the west in their relation to their context, covering much of the 20th century.

“So her book’s form can only emerge from her complete immersion in the images from her memory in order to identify, with relative certainty, the specific signs of the times, the years to which the images belong, gradually linking them to others; to try to hear the words people spoke, what they said about they said about events and things, skim it off the mads of floating speech, that hubbub that tirelessly ferries the wordings of what we are and we must be, think, believe, fear, and hope.” The author described what she set out to do and did so brilliantly in describing the events in her life, from the macro, WW Ii and the destruction of the World Trade Center, to the micro, a holiday dinner with her sons and their partners or shopping at a hypermarket. The allusions to figures or events in France alluded me (too lazy to look them all up) but that did not detract from the feelings that this book evoked in me. Don’t we all have memories of family dinners, but I am unable to capture them in the evocative language of this author.
The best

The form is the thing: the richness in the innovation but also the innovation's weakness.  As she lays out the objects, events, years...I found three types of responses in myself: There were names/events/things that I remember and have my own memories of -- like the 45 of Joe Dassin that I own and sang with; there were names/events/things that I could imagine as she told them -- like the deaths of famous people; and then there were times when there was no overlap between her narrator's memory and mine.  What I like is the premise that there is nothing private. That all memories are of a we" and never rooted in a singular "I". There is something very structural in her method but a structure with particulars.  But what I miss is the narrative voice that creates the arc. There IS an arc in the book as a whole. But what I want something that connects the life "we" lived. The effect of the book is as if memory were recorded in pixels. What I want is the pixels AND an overall picture with its meaning.  So the form is innovative and even mind blowing -- if you have the patience to stick with it

review": 4.75/5  A worthwhile read that triggers contemplation.  The ability to translate a work like this, specifically from French to English, is a feat deserving of an award; much praise to Strayer.  4.75, and not 5.00, because I felt the last ten pages, where the book itself was explained, took away from the beauty of the artwork itself. The entire book is a sort of dual autobiography, constantly alternating between a story of the author herself, and a collective autobiography of France and/or women in France. By spending the last ten pages discussing the inspiration/design/inception of the book, the perspective snaps exclusively to Ernaux's and we lose the collective point of view. In addition, it's always nice to go behind the scenes and see how and why iconic art was made, but I would prefer that the pulling back of the curtain on this book's creation not be part of the artwork itself.  Then again, this book won a Nobel Prize and I'm just an idiot with a keyboard. You should read this.

review": Ernaux very ably tracks a life from the first inchoate impressions and on through the years. Merging words, books, cinema, fashion, politics and giving us clear snapshots for all the years. Changing tone for the changing years.  I imagine the great amount of research undertaken to build up this book. I think that if I were French, I would have formed a greater connection to the book. As it is, most of the references flew right by me, so I lost a lot because of that. That and the aloofness she maintains throughout the book are I think what made me not enjoy this as much as I thought I would.  An ARC kindly provided by author/publisher Fitzcarraldo, via Netgalley.

This didn’t resonate with me at all. Reflecting on the why:  Ernaux is around the age of my grandma and their lives probably started in quite similar post-war village style. Ok, only the gulags were very real here. Through the years, their storylines split in incredible way, it’s half a century of parallel lives, completely different. This unfairness bugs me always - that my parents and granparents couldn’t enjoy the same freedom and the problems that come with having freedom.  Then there’s a generational gap, which makes me read this book as some strange work of history, where events come one after another, some i’m aware of, some not, but mostly they give me a “meh” feeling. I can reason with myself that it’s incredible, how much changed in a lifetime, but so what.  The flow of time is a theme of many books, and French have their line starting with Proust (who reappears here too, with his Madeleines). I learned to love the flow of time by Proust. Recently I was surprised by how tasty and sensual is the flow of Duras. Here? Again, meh.  Maybe because the author tries to disconnect from herself and looks to her life from the observer point of view (but then, Proust was also a very much observer). There’s not much emotions - maybe because the author used up her feelings for earlier books. I found it dull, lacking of spices.  Or is it just my French and I didn’t read through a layer that was left for the native readers? In some books I easily recognise my limitations, here it doesn’t seem to be the case. As librarian said - the language is even too simplistic. Maybe that’s what bothered me.  On one podcast they’ve said Les Années is not the best book to start with, so maybe i should try some earlier ones. But then, French literature is full of authors i truly enjoy exploring. Maybe this one can wait until i retire, or smth

I nearly gave this one star because I’ve never been so simultaneously bored and interested by a book. The Years is both an autobiography of Annie Ernaux and a sort of cultural chronicle of France from the 1940s to 2008.  Every paragraph was a new thought/image/topic - all sharp and visceral, but the constant barrage quickly became exhausting. Ernaux talks about herself in the third person and about her generation/ the French people using the first person plural, which I also did not like and felt preachy.  I did like how the evolution of the country’s wider hopes, dreams and ideologies was interwoven with changes in the smallest details of daily life and the representations and actualities of sex in French culture. The threads were perfectly balanced and consistent. I must also concede that Ernaux is a good writer. I just didn’t really enjoy 220 pages of jerky dogmatic nostalgia. This is a strangely dispassionate but effective assembling of ‘history’ - the ‘slippery narrative’ of experience against a larger backdrop continually assessed, addressed, which, in turn, forms an intrinsic part of Ernaux herself.  This philosophical approach, at turns existentialist and Freudian will find its greatest devotees in lovers of French thought and culture - or at least old enough to recall many of the events described throughout its pages.  And fans of of Flaubert, Proust, de Beauvoir and Sagan will find the familiar overtones of regret and sadness that echo throughout French life-writing and literature.

review": Personal Handwritten Notes — The dissolution of the ‘I’ into the ‘we’; we are all nameless by default. — For the impersonal to become personal, we must express ourselves freely. — Acquainting and thus expressing oneself through the films and the literature of the zeitgeist is perhaps the highest form of personal expression. — There is a lean emphasis on rebellion and counterculture. This seems to support postmodern thinking, but Ernaux still remains firmly rooted in her kin. — There is also a need to keep track of current events as a sign of ‘intellectual gentrification’. Out with the old; in with the new. This ensures that one’s freedom is not misguided. This is ironic because Ernaux also uses her freedom to masturbate to porn, though one may argue that it is her way of expressing her sexuality. — ‘New objects were no longer met with wonder or anxiety, but welcomed as additions to individual freedom and pleasure.’ — Although freedom entails active autonomy, there is a recumbent sort of lassitude acquainted with it—that it is, in one way or another, man’s eschatological state-of-being. Nothing comes out of it thereafter. — This freedom is further augmented by the fact that these objects are made for one’s own individual pleasure. For instance, one does not need to learn how to code in order to use a computer. Freedom is as personal as it is necessary. — ‘Nothing equaled the bliss at the end of the day, after elbowing one’s way with the first passengers into the crowded RER, and inching as close as possible to the center aisle seats, and standing for these stations, of finally sitting down and closing one’s eyes, or doing a crossword.’ — This freedom; however, is impermanent, for there remains the looming global threat of civil war that seems to have resurfaced after 9/11. Thus, in spite of the inert implications of personal expression, we are led to question whether one is truly free or simply a configuration of all and sundry forces as a consequence of this so-called ‘intellectual gentrification’. — ‘The time for sleep was past. We had to be alert until the end of time.’ — ‘There was a consensual falsity in the air.’ We are free but we acknowledge that this freedom may not last. — In lieu of this, we have configured reality in such a way that personal freedom is achieved by manipulating freedom such that it is attainable within the bounds of our own realities. Hence, freedom becomes reproducible and our conception of ‘we’ transforms into a multiplicity of singular, nondescript ‘I’s. — ‘We lived in a profusion of everything, objects, information, and “expert opinions”. No sooner had an event occurred than someone issued a reflection, whatever the subject: manners of conduct, the body, orgasm, and euthanasia. Everything was discussed and decrypted.’ — ‘With the intermingling of concepts, it was increasingly difficult to find a phrase of one’s own, the kind that, when silently repeated, helped one live.’ — Ernaux comes to the conclusion that one’s freedom—or personal expression—should not be thought of as a unique ‘I’ that exists differentiated in comparison to the larger populace, but as a replicated ‘I’ out of an impersonal ‘we’ that exists only as a function of depicting reality at its nth configuration. — ‘There is no “I” in what she views as a sort of impersonal autobiography. There is only “one” and “we”, as if now it were her turn to tell the story of the time-before.’ — The memoir—if it even can be called one—begins and ends in images, for what are we but spectators of reality?

Book club book #29 The arc of a life - the author - and of the world from 1941 to 2006. The effect is detached observation, like walking through a museum. Photos, videos, places, memories are described. The story is life, the emotions are “every person”, we get the odd sense of knowing everything about the author - and nothing. It is a grand narrative, condensed into 225 pages, that is elegantly, tightly written, but is hard to connect with emotionally except towards the end as her children have children, and she begins to confront death.

The past is a foreign country  Ernaux contemplates her life throughout the second half of the 20th century and uses it as a narrative arc for the portrait of the generation of French women. Both Didier Eribon and Édouard Louis named Ernaux as their inspiration for describing their experience as class emigrants. However, I could see only traces of that theme in The Years. The focus here is less on class and more on female experience. The legalisation of abortion, 1968, normalisation of what was previously seen as aberration or immorality etc. are topics that Ernaux mentions. The writing itself resembled a series of brief notes, often using a lot of cultural references that would be hard to follow to anyone a) not growing up in France in the period or b) not deeply immersed in French culture already. The Polish translation helpfully provided numerous footnotes explaining the events and characters, but also correcting factual errors made by the author. It was an engaging read but nowhere as good as Returning to Reims.

I struggled with this book (literally struggling to stay awake reading it in the afternoon), until the years when the events described were within my own living memory. I feel I need to go back and reread the book, because it’s experimental and I didn’t understand the experiment until closer to it’s end.  Ernaux writes a piercing critique of capitalism and American imperialism, but also of French racism (so similar to British!) and the ineffectual nature of western democratic processes and movements like feminism.  I understand the trajectory of my own life better for having read this work. I now understand it as a masterpiece (mistresspiece?) and sense I’ll get even more from it when I reread it.

A masterpiece! With this my take is that Ernaux creates a whole new genre that takes a few pages to get used to, but once you’re in it it connects you to the described images, the personal memories and the indirect reflections on society’s collective memory and experiences in a way that is both fascinating at times so spot on that it’s almost uncomfortable to read. There are so many great wordings and quotes that I will definitely have to read this again sometime just to relive and better remember those phrasings. Solid 5 stars.

Another wonderful book by Ernaux. I loved the author’s long strings of historical or sociological observations. As my wife said to me, it’s somehow incredibly refreshing to see an author do away with all of the often unnecessary transition phrases we encounter so often. Here, there is no “therefore” or “however” or “nevertheless” or “on the other hand.” There is only the unrelenting flow of ideas. Of course, I also loved the powerful feminist insight that accrues from her close scrutiny of her body, her sexual life, her interactions with men, and her encounters with consumerism and policies related to abortion, etc. And it’s wonderful to compare her treatment of the flow of biographical or autobiographical time with Woolf’s and Proust’s and Lahiri’s.

“Sauver quelque chose du temps où l'on ne sera plus jamais.”― Annie Ernaux, Les Années.  I mean WOW. This IS a masterpiece memoir of French life. It is a uniquely genius autobiography, which can also be easily treated as a lesson in history and culture between 1940s and 2000s.  The book spans the timeframe from Ernaux’s birth in 1940 up to 2006, and moves from her working-class upbringing in Normandy to her years teaching French literature in a lycée, living in the Parisian suburb of Cergy, raising two sons and eventually divorcing.  However, it is not a straightforward autobiography; rather it is told in a collective “we”, which sometimes shifts into the third person, so the author appears as “she”. Ernaux shows it is possible to write both personally and collectively, situating her own story within the story of her generation, without ever confusing the two. She reflects on the book she is writing even as she writes it, resolving: “There is no ‘I’ in what she views as a sort of impersonal autobiography. There is only ‘one’ and ‘we’, as if now it were her time to tell the story of the time-before.”  The memoir is comprised of Ernaux's own memories, of historical events, of scraps of popular culture, slang, notes on the subtle transformations of the culture.  In the memoir, we encounter the war in Algeria, Sartre and De Beauvoir, Edith Piaf’s “Les Amants d’un Jour,” fondue bourguignonne, Agnès Varda’s Le Bonheur, the pro-abortion rights manifesto of the 343 salopes, nuclear threat, the explosion of consumerism, unemployment, immigration, the advance of technology.   Truly genius.

A very interesting combination of auto biographical and historical pieces of France from 1940s forward. This is highly regional in my opinion and the copious sentences in French and obscure references to events only locals would understand left me disinterested.

I found it very hard to get through. If I had more connection to the country of France, I can see how cool it would be to read, what is in essence, the autobiography of a country if a country could write. To me the book lacked emotion, it felt very dry. The writing was beautiful, though.

Beautifully authentic piece. It took me practically to the end to truly understand why Ernaux decided on this kaleidoscopically impersonal third person perspective. An understanding which perhaps is only truly earned retrospectively, rather than concurrently, with the text. For Ernaux life, the life of the “self,” belongs to a broader discourse, a greater unfolding and eventuating through which we are able to manifest - even if on uncertain terms - images, visions, of a shared essence.  4.5/5

In 2022, it was a delight to discover the work of Annie Ernaux. I quickly fell in love with her crisp yet poetic prose and her vulnerable style of entangling memories.  So it was only fitting to start 2023 with The Years, Ernaux’s ambitious attempt to chronicle the years between 1941 and 2006 through memory, media and mundanity.  Inventing a new form referred to as ‘the collective autobiography,’ she captures the passing of time with fragments and snapshots. The Years is a slim book and Ernaux deftly glides between both precise moments and fleeting impressions. This captures the feeling of understanding what it was like to live then, whether through a political reference or a conversation between family or friends.  The way she takes us through a big historical event and simple domestic life on the same page is astounding. After all, when we look back on our lives, the most random things seem more real than the incidents in history books.  I particularly loved the recurring motif of how family meals have changed over the years. The tables may stay the same but people evolve, relationships evolve and conversations evolve as Ernaux grows from child to young woman to wife to mother.  I also loved how meta it was, as Ernaux reflects on her own images and videos and wonders who she was then. There’s also discussions of how to create the very text that you are reading, which I found fascinating.  This may be a work of sociology, but the lyricism and musings are always present.

review": This book caught my eye at a bookstore because I noticed the author had won the Nobel Prize and I hadn’t read any books by French female writers before. The concept of the book is quite unique indeed, and I’ve never read an autobiography that also tells the story of the author’s generation and the passing of time as collective community.  Since she only writes in impersonal pronouns, I found the book harder to relate to. I thought the most interesting parts of the books were when she described her own life rather than historical events. I think as an American, I didn’t have much context and couldn’t follow along with most of the French historical events she spoke about. Due to these reasons, I wouldn’t say the book was the most enjoyable read, but I will say it may me think in a new way.  I rarely think about the context of my life and experiences in a greater historical context, and it is an interesting exercise to think about what “snapshots” within my life I would write about in a memoir. I don’t think I fully understood why she chose each specific photograph she wrote about throughout her life, but I liked the theme of these photographs and the theme of the family dinners. The book didn’t have any chapters, so these recurring plot points helped give the narrative more structure.  I’m curious to read more about how French audiences relate to her work, since she is one of the most famous living French writers today. It was really cool how open and honest she was about her relationships, wanting to get a divorce, not remarrying and having many flings as an older woman. She certainly breaks the mold of a traditional older woman.  Overall, an interesting read but not sure if I would recommend to the average American reader.

The Years is a beautiful book. Part memoir, Ernaux traces the contours of her life against the the social and political events of France. Using a unique narrative structure, she examines our own relationship with our past selves. I am hesitant (and maybe unable) to describe the book much beyond this, except to say it was infinitely enjoyable, emotional, informative, and intimate.
The concept is original and the descriptions are often beautiful. The constant references make it difficult for non-french, but it provides an insight into the culture.

This one has a different scope than her other works: most of it is an overview of France in the last half of the 20th century up until the early aught's, and how French society, then the world as technology made the world feel nearer, has changed in that time. Her attempt to be objective at times verges on the glib in the face of inhumanity. It is only towards the end when it becomes classic Ernaux, focusing on her development as a writer and how she used to think about herself and her profession in light of how the world was changing around her, does it become passionate and personable. It's in those passages the best moments of the book can be found. Not nearly as enthralling as La Femme Gelee or Une Femme, which I think as time goes on will be seen as her masterpieces, followed by Passion Simple.

This is a very interesting memoir, written through the collective memory of all of French culture throughout the years between post WWII to 2008. If that sounds overwhelmingly comprehensive, it is and it isn’t. She covers lots of events that happened during those years, but the style is very superficial, almost like a bulleted list. Except that the list is written by a Nobel prize winner, so it’s literary and beautifully done. Layered over this running context is her own story about having children, having a career, getting divorced, growing older. There’s so little detail about her - it’s like a whisper of who she is. And layered over her personal story is a meta essay about how she is going to write this book. Did I love it? Not really, because I didn’t feel that invested in her as a character, and I’m hopelessly American and ignorant of much of the culture in France that she writes about. But some of the writing, particularly her observations about her children and about her own aging, left me breathless with their beauty and personal truth.

It took me a little while to get into this book but once I did, I really enjoyed it. Such an interesting and unique format - it’s been called a ‘collective autobiography’ and that’s a pretty apt description. It recounts the contemporary history of France through a series of fragments, memories, snapshots from Ernaux - with allusions to her own life made throughout through the collective ‘we’. It made me think about how different generations relate to the politics, culture, media spectacles of the day, how they have shaped us and continue to shape us. It was also a very readable and engaging reflection on French history - from the post-war years to 1968 to the Chirac presidency.
I am still processing this book but I loved it because she and I shared this time period in different places. She gave me the gift of words to describe my similar experiences.

Unlike any memoir I have ever read; a collective journey through the past several decades. I felt particularly attached to her description of the journey of women's rights and her description at the end on the passing of time. Worth the read.

Wow. A book, a story, a history, an autobiography that is both breathfilled and breathless in it’s telling. Even in its reading, it left me feeling full of life and breathless, aware of the transient and overlapping nature of time, which Ernaux expresses, seemingly impossibly, in words.  Benjamin and Proust clearly influence Ernaux’s thinking, yet the way in which she grounds their complex ideas of time in social, cultural, political, and personal events over a span of 60 years makes those ideas come alive in a new, magical way.  I found this book full of lessons in the craft of writing nonfiction as well. Ernaux is an inspiration.

Crazy what changes and events people born during World War II have witnessed throughout their lives. With modern medicine enabling people to live longer (a trend that also intensified during that time in Western countries), it’s only natural that a single average person is able to witness more societal progress throughout their lives. But the sheer waves of new technology and political movements from 1940 to 2010 are probably unlike anything else in the history of civilization.  It’s exciting to read such an eloquent recounting of all these developments from an intimate individual perspective like this. I wonder if this book is more exciting if you didn’t actually live through that time yourself. Because I clearly became less interested once the book arrived in the era for which I already had more hisitorical knowledge before reading.  Especially the parts that were more Franco-centric were interesting, in that regard, compared to the more big-picture events in the more recent „globalized world“ since I didn’t have that distinct of an idea of what life in France was like in the 1940s or 1950s.

I read the English translation, which was excellent and did a wonderful job of staying true to the author’s voice while helping readers who might not be familiar with all of the French references. While the writing style takes a bit of getting used to, Annie is a brilliant writer who encapsulates key truths about life that resonated with so many readers(I read it for an international book club and the discussion was richly layered). I highly recommend this Nobel winner’s work!!

Intimate, confessional yet written in a depersonalized style- the writer observing the intimate life of the self on the social/historical backdrop of post-war France. She charts her own history from a provincial conservative town, to being middle class housewife, and then finally as a somewhat liberated Parisian writer who sifts through her own disjoined family and French media memories, regarding them in a modern light. A friend in our book club teased her middle class politics and sensibilities- she was born a half generation earlier than the student movement of 1968, which she viewed at the time through a somewhat jaundiced/envious suburban lens. Political, erotic, full of ennui- so very French, but readable and formally striking as a sort of dissociated social autobiography.

She won the Noble Prize and is regarded as France's greatest living writer, but this memory book, which I read in translation, was not really my thing -- although the memories of a post war, left wing French woman who delves into life and politics and gender is definitely interesting in places. She reminds us what it was like to be a poor girl in pre-Abortion, small town France, frightened about the events in Algeria and the pullout from Vietnam, and dominated by one pompous leader after another (DeGaulle, D'Estaing, etc.). But it is a different genre than I am used to -- it quite literally is memories”….sometimes

review": Ernaux’ capacity to revive past times is totally impressive. Her work is much more than a recollection of facts and personal memories. It is an intense attempt at rendering her own state of mind through times, and by extension the one of the society she evolved in. And she does an amazing job at it. Facts are usually easy to recollect but often difficult to grasp without context. By rendering feelings and common unspoken sensations of the times, she helps the reader to make sense of it all. The book might be more relevant to French people, who can relate with the numerous cultural/societal landmarks she evokes. But it will give any reader a fascinating vertigo-like sensation when realising how many transformations our societies have gone through in the space of just a few decades.

As one who hasn't studied French or French history, and a couple generations removed from the author's, I was struck by the universality of experiences across generations and nationalities. Ernaux is a genius and this is a breathtaking memoir. It is original in every way. The style enables her to interrogate her life rather than report it. There is a high-level “we” narrator whose vision is sociological and psychological. The subject is positioned within the larger context of culture. It is her story but also a story of the time, of a generation, and of a generational post-war shift in French consciousness. Within that shift are dramatic changes in the public and private lives of women.

i read this for a class, and i don't think i would've made it past the first 30 pages if not for the assignment looming over my head. it starts out very disorienting with a list of items seemingly unrelated to each other, but as i kept reading, i understood that the details in this book aren't about themselves but about creating the whole picture of the moments in time she narrates. the good parts are *really* good, but they're very spread out throughout the book. there are some really, really poignant statements about the passage of time and the transcendence of memory (made me want to combust immediately) hidden among lots of other words that just aren't very engaging. it definitely feels more like a collage than a story. too many proper nouns; not enough narrative. it only became an enjoyable read once i started ignoring half the references and just rolled with the vibes. i generally liked it. maybe i'll revisit it when i feel like contemplating time a bit more.  oh i also skimmed past the second half during the hour before my class so maybe i just missed the whole point.

Very interesting! I had to read this twice to underline things I remember (Ernaux is 12 years older). She writes a memoir of the years and her life 1941-2006 in France. I love the way she starts by describing a picture of herself as a baby and a 1 year old. Beautiful writing. She remembers only a couple things (the wallpaper, the outside yard) and then as she gets older, friends, class differences, food they ate, what they did at catholic church. They were so serious. Later, older still, she describes books they used in college, what the elders talked about, political positions, manners, pasting Tour de France winners in a scrapbook. She moved to Paris for school: the clothes, the concerts, how it felt to be 22, married, a son, and on she goes. Toward the end, you read it for wisdom and what she learned about politics, relationships, and war. A short book, a decent book. Ultimately it is about how our memories play tricks on us. Nice to know it was picked for the Nobel Prize in Literature 2022.

This book, by the recent Nobel Prize winner, is fascinating. It is a kind of memoir, but the word 'I' is rarely or never used, rather it is written in terms of 'we' and 'she'. This is consistent with the telling of the life in a style that is like that of a news reporter, describing what is happening much more than what is being felt. Indeed, the sense that is conveyed is that the life being described happened to the writer, rather than being lived by her. And what happens seems to be composed of societal and historical trends and happenings much more than interpersonal experiences. Unique and, for me, kind of unsettling.

Annie Ernaux was a teacher all her working life but also a professor and an esteemed writer of many subjects written in the style of memoir-as-social-history and told by an enjoyable storyteller. I previously read a shorter story by Ernaux of an incident in her personal life that took place during the early 1960’s. She didn’t dwell on that life experience at all in this memoir although the ‘60’s did take up a good part of the nearly seven decades that she had lived, and recalled with the help of her journals, diaries and notes.  It was the author's personal quest and she had always planned to write a book of the life she lived and the times she went through. Born in France in 1940, she gathered experiences and insights that only grew until 2006 when she became the narrator of her story but never used the personal pronoun “I” in what she viewed as a sort of impersonal autobiography. “All that the world has impressed upon her and her contemporaries she will use to reconstitute a common time, the one that made its way through the years of the distant past and glided all the way to the present. By retrieving the memory of collective memory in an individual memory, she will capture the lived dimension of History.” p228.  Because Ernaux was born and lived in France the names of French movies and television, politicians, musicians, places, authors, etc. are different from those that I was familiar with growing up. It was a bit frustrating to not know of these people or books or music or places and it slowed down my interest. America had its’ own social issues and problems every 4 years, electing its’ next leader, and yet her interpretations and concerns could be universal. I experienced the same types of influences which impacts most of us while growing older. The writer expertly captured the pace of social change, and demonstrated how values and ways of living alter over the years, in an unpredictable way. Different from our own parents and different from that of our children. So interesting.  I could hardly wait until after 9/11/2001 and the other events until she sums up her life and begins to establish what, she realized over the years, was most important. To tell the story from her generational perspective as a woman, student protester, wife, mother, devorcee, etc. was important. To keep the memories alive even after she is no longer there to tell the stories. Each of us could tell our own story but it would lack the talent and conviction to speak of things we had been aware of but couldn’t find the words to explain. “The Years” could be relating to millions of people of that generation subjected to their own influences across the globe.  As a writer, Ernaux has been recognized for her contributions to the world and became the recipient of the 2022 Nobel Prize in Literature. We are lucky to be living at a time when translations by remarkable professional translators of such gifted writers from all over the world are available. Alison L. Strayer wrote “A Translator’s Note” afterword which added to my gratitude to a story well told. I will be searching for more by Annie Ernaux.

Called “the collective autobiography”, ‘The Years’ by Annie Ernaux is a splendid blend of humanity moving through time along with intimate observations of the author in regards to her own life and experience. It is the antithesis of self-centric and reminds the reader of that which touches the lives of all people… or most… or cross-sections. It feels at once personal and private and yet, recognizably choral. I loved this style of storytelling. It was impactful.  It’s a quiet telling, with an underlying urgency. The consciousness and perception of “the people” shifting with the passage of time. It’s poetic and sharp.  Something I noted was the universal nature of it. From cycles of war, poverty and revolution to the prejudices and oppression that came back into mainstream society over and over again, to the realization that France, through time, is not that different than America… than the UK… all places built on euro-centric values and colonization of others. It made me detest those in power and feel for the people impacted by those “leaders” and felt a sense of empathy for those on either side of political and religious dividing lines— in that we are all victims of the eternal greed, hate and power hungry monsters. But at each of these cycles Ernaux acknowledges the importance of that pushing-back, so often led or carried forward, by the next generation.  It deals beautifully with a woman’s journey, as well, from childhood through college and marriage and becoming a mother then life post divorce. The nuances of inner rebellion and the shifting of passions.  Annie Ernaux is such a powerhouse! So glad I’ve decided to read her essentials this year!

This is an intoxicating read for anyone who has lived through a similar time and place which is 1946 - 2006 France. It is a collage of the author’s life, written like a diary but probably retrospective. My interest increased when she got to the year of my own birth because we always care more about what happened after our own arrival on the planet.  The Years stimulates memories of the reader’s own life and will evoke any of the reader's experiences of France or the French. The comparison between different generations peppers the narrative. One minute she’s remembering her parents and then she’s relating something her adult children said over dinner. Early childhood and teenage years seemed to go more slowly just like real-life. Overall, this book is a replaying a grainy video of her life.  Throughout the book, there are snippets of world events like having the radio on in the background in the 1940s and ’50s, then the television in the 1960s, 70s, and 80. It seems to speed up in the 90s when information is coming through the phone and the Internet. There are lots of references to famous French people and news events so this would be more enjoyable if you knew all of those. It is a journey into France’s past where you can’t help but compare it with your own country. A comparison between Catholic Ireland and Catholic France shows how Ireland took about twenty to thirty years longer than France to shake off the stranglehold the church had on society.  Not sure how successful this book would be if it moved past 2006 into the age of misinformation, false facts, and conspiracy theories. That’s another book for a younger person – possibly Patricia Lockwood.

I loved reading this. I’m finding myself comforted in a time of extreme anxiety by reading books that help me situate myself in the world, in time, in the U.S., in capitalism. Things feel so bad to me at the moment, that reminders that things haven’t always been this way, that we’ve rapidly acclimated to new and shitty conceptions of normal, are helpful and calming to my nerves. There were many times, really the whole reading experience, that I was surprised this was written in 2008 and not 2022 — everything feels like it’s happening for the first time when we don’t study history. (I want to get better)  I’m glad I had read some Ernaux before I read this, and would recommend the same to other readers (though this certainly stands on its own). This isn’t autofiction, but autobiography + world history. I feel there needs to be some sort of distinction between Ernaux’s brand of autofiction (good) and the kind that’s saturating the market right now (absolutely nothing to say, but the authors decided they want to be authors). Someone articulate has probably already articulated this. What I mean to say is, Ernaux is worth reading for anyone.

The nearly complete absence of the first person in this very personal memoir is an enormous part of its appeal. That we all live out our lives amid and among other humans (including their music, politics, biases, expressions, values, religion, etc.) may seem obvious, but Ernaux artfully makes her story ours by bringing all this into lyrical clarity. In doing so, she also gives us a new understanding of memory - not only how memory works in us individually, but how it works across generations.

The Years is both an individual and generational memoir covering the years 1941-2006. Although it is based on Annie Ernaux’s personal experience, rather than writing in the first person,with its corresponding “I”, she chooses the plural pronoun “we.” In this way she more fully captures the historical and cultural experiences of her generation, particularly that of French women, and produces what in some ways represents a sociological text.  I was unfamiliar with several of the French historical and cultural figures she mentions as well as some of the films and music she refers to, but I did get a great sense of the times she lived through, and the challenges women faced (movingly recounted through Ernaux’s own individual experience), particularly regarding their sexual freedom and self-expression. The Years is an illuminating book which reveals both the life of an artist and her country. Ennaux was awarded the 2022 Nobel Prize in Literature.

I was initially confused as to why there was a gap of 10 years between its original publication in French (so well received, a leading argument in favor of her winning the Nobel), but now I know.  Littered with references to French history and culture, I found myself lost at times, especially in the years between the history that is taught and the history that is lived (events must stew before being declared notable). But if I ignored my ignorance (treating it being too time-consuming for this season of my life), I could appreciate the scope of the work and its attempt to capture the lived dimension of History" "by retrieving the memory of collective memory in an individual memory" (222). A brilliant memoir of a woman growing up in post WWII France -- and as much a memoir as a social history. The tone and structure are boldly creative and soothing, like watching an old home movie of black and white images drift across a screen. Her constant movement from first person singular, to first person plural, to third person is, for me, effective in placing the author's emotions under a microscope and -- at the same time -- positioning her life and experiences in the social and historical context of post war France.

A truly fascinating book that resembles nothing I've read before. Ernaux is a master of l’écriture plate, with her simple, unadorned prose that is still strong enough to carry heavy themes, emotional baggage, and stylistic ingenuity. I felt that the translation was stunning-- Alison Strayer somehow managed to communicate the nuance of nous and on into English as Ernaux carefully sidesteps the autobiography of je.  I was also struck by the unusual format of the book, which felt both completely natural and brand new. Ernaux's life is peeled back in layers, each examined and analyzed by a detached, present-day narrator. Time collapses inward as Ernaux searches for clarity and finds none. Interspersed with her photographs of the past (described clinically, critically), Ernaux assumes the mantle of collective historian. She inventories life in mid- to late-20th-century France, sensitive to its political and social stirrings, tracking the rise of consumer capitalism and the cancerous growth of anti-immigrant and racist sentiments. I spent a lot of the book thinking about 1) how infrequently women are permitted to become the voice of a generation" and document collective history

This was an interesting read and a very interesting way to structure a nonfiction biographical story that skips through the time periods around world war 2 (i am not completely sure if it starts when the author herself was born 1940 or a little early or later? but around there) until 2016 (?).  it gives little snippets of insight into the historical moments, daily life and typical moments of the country during the times, reading almost like flipping through a photoalbum and getting little thoughts and memories of the person that put the album together.  it reminded me a bit if „Ducks, Newburyport“ in the way it was written (even though i am pretty sure this book „the years“ was written before the one i just mentioned but i read the other one before reading this one …) in that it felt as if we as the readers are getting the wandering thoughts of a person on topics -or in this books case specific times in history- but never to deep and in-depth but simple remembering something, shortly thinking about it before letting the mind wander on to the next topics.   i personally found that not the best style for a nonfiction work. if i get information about historical moments be it big evens or typical daily lives of everyday work people i want a bit more details. i want to be able to understand and feel and picture what is happening.  and sure in a way with this book and time time periods it talks about that is possible since most of us either have parents or grandparents that are in a similar age as the author and if you are European it’s very likely that -if the survived the ww2- they shared at least a little about the time around and/or after or what it was like growing up during a time directly after a horrendous war that left many places in europe in shambles. also it is still pretty recent history and i would hope that most countries still teach the aftermaths of ww2.  what i mean with saying all that is that even without too many details a good of readers will understand most of what’s being said because in many cases it could connect with a personal story they have been told or something similar.  but is it really a good book and well written if it’s leans pretty heavily on the believe that the reader will have a basic understanding of those times in France and specifically Paris to fill in the missing pieces to make it all actually be meaningful?  clearly it is working since most other reviews i have seen so far from this book are highly rated and raving about how wonderful and even emotional this book and the reading experience was for them.  and i do understand how that could be that way…. but again maybe not necessarily because of how fantastic this book tells what it says but rather because the way it reminds readers of things?  and if that was the purpose? well done!  but again i do not read autobiographical nonfictions to get snippets and skips through time that feel rather impersonal to the authors life.   i think this is a clear case of what you want from this type of book and how you will enjoy the writing style and what you want to read into the book.   if you want a clear cut nonfiction that just tells you the what and how? not the book for you!  if you want a book that is different and a bit strange not your typical nonfiction? go for it!

This took me longer to read than I initially thought; it’s a tough read that made me feel uncomfortable, in essence it did what Ernaux set out to do.  The Years is told in vignettes from 1940 to 2006, it is an autobiography told by Ernaux but not about Ernaux… it is France’s autobiography told through memories and perceptions.  Ernaux uses the collective “we” but throws in some “they” and “she” which at times made it difficult for me to separate her from the French collective she was conveying. Primarily I found I had to keep reminding myself that certain atrocious statements / views were not those of Ernaux but those she saw the majority French public convey as she lived the events.  It’s a tricky narrative tackling difficult subjects; war, human rights, consumerism, racism / right-wing politics - I could go on; in 227 pages Ernaux serves it all.  I recommend taking your time with this one and digesting it fully once you’re done; allowing you to process the full effect of this rare narrative style.

The Years is a memoir by Annie Ernaux, covering the period from the end of WWII to the early 2000s in France. It flits between recollections of her past–framed by descriptions of personal photographs– and vignettes about moments in history and pop culture shared by her generation. The memoir encapsulates so much, but what resonanted with me most was her exploration of how we develop a conciousness about the state of the world and then grow to willfully stifle that consience, knowing full well that, as Ernaux puts it, a 'secure profession' and money [doesn't] necessarily bring happiness."  And then (since Ernaux loves lists): -How do we feel the invisble threads of history sewing us together

And her collective commentary on childhood, on teenage years, on womanhood in its various stages all rang true. My book group read it and the discussion was very engaging.

It started in a strange way, it took time to get used to the numerous social and cultural references, which I did not get because I was not too familiar with France of the 40-50s but then it just became ingrained in my reading experience. I considered *** but the book certainly deserves *****. Annie Ernaux has the wonderful ability to evoke memories of an entire society or decade in a few lines, just through simple pictures and no explanation. This strength was my problem - Not French and/or not old enough, I am not able to fully follow her without extensive research on the side.

But these were not real memories. That was the name we gave them, but in fact they were something quite different: markers of an epoch.  A dense, rich work charting life in France from 1941 to 2006. It covers both the narrator's interior life and the changing political and cultural landscape over the decades. The lack of formal chapters and scrapbook-like structure creates a run-on effect reminiscent of the passing of time, making for an immersive reading experience. I really enjoyed the Proustian elements of memory, both collective and individual, and how we constantly shape and reframe one through the lens of the other. Some of my favourites parts were those focused on family rituals, where the participants change roles and ages but the overall scene remains largely unchanged over generations.

Ernaux weaves personal memoir with commentary on France’s evolving social and political landscape over the decades from 1940 to 2007 and places it in a broader global context. Anyone well versed in French history will find this a fascinating journey. I personally had difficulty connecting to the material for the first 75 pages or so, laboriously sifting through French pop culture references that were meaningless to me. I’m terrible enough when it comes to pop culture I grew up with… For that reason it was helpful to read with an English translation as companion, as reassurance in those moments of self doubt. So happy I persevered. My comprehension frustrations diminished as I became swept up in Ernaux’ captivating language and astute observations such that I was able to integrate myself into her stories and history and feel a part of the “je collectif.”

Really enjoyed this book. A lot of the author's perspective came from events in Europe, but there were also as many world events that impacted her views as well. A book that will definitely make you think about your own life and how you experienced similar events. Well done!
