I can truly say I have never read a book like this one before. It is at once a memoir, a scrapbook, a collage of personal memories mixed with pop culture, political/societal climate analysis, and poetic imagery. Impressions of daily life, radio, television, advertisements, news headlines, beginning in France in the 1940s and spanning decades. I want one for every country, for every profession, every demographic, for every life I have not lived and will never know. Themes of feminism, sexual liberation, identity, materialism, are set in an intensely poetic and thoughtful narrative, though at times it could be a tad difficult to follow - references to lesser-known events in French history that required footnotes or a Wikipedia search. But more often, Ernaux wrote of universal human experiences - confusion, love, loss. It felt very Sylvia Plath. Overall, reading this novel made me feel so very very nostalgic for an entire life I have never lived. I think this is what reading is all about. This is why I do it. Five stars.

Every page of The Years (2008) by Annie Ernaux was like a nutritious bouillon cube that kept dissolving in my thoughts for hours. I do not think I have ever read such condensed prose. It was filled to the brim with reflections, observations and images rooted in the memory of the author, who narrates not only her life, but also the experiences of her generation born during the Second World War. Humour mixes with poetry, politics with individual experience, literature with reality. I think most writers would need multitudes of 256 pages to tell a similar story. Annie Ernaux's succinct, lucid and precise writing style is her memoir's forte.  I wonder if there is a single page in this book on which I have not marked a passage that either made me laugh or marvel at Annie Ernaux's brilliance or simply moved me. Like other readers, I have the impression that if I were born around 1940, preferably in France, I would find even more in The Years. My enjoyment was hampered a bit by the need to check some historical details.  Compared to the memoirs I have read before, The Years is quite unique. Of course, the title made me think of Virginia Woolf's The Years though, which is also a poignant chronicle of fleeting moments. The detailed descriptions of family photos (how I wish the real photographs were included!) reminded me of W.G. Sebald's Austerlitz .  Although The Years is undoubtfully autobiographical, the narrator avoids using the pronoun 'I', it is always 'she' or 'we'. I guess the author's intention here was to distance herself from her experiences, to look at herself from the outside and more objectively, and to emphasise that she is not just an individual but a part of her generation too.  I liked Annie Ernaux's luminous prose, full of the images of a moment, bathed in a light that is theirs alone and kept trying to read The Years as slowly as possible to make the literary bliss last longer. It is not solely Annie Ernaux's merit but also the translator's. Alison L. Strayer did a marvellous job and her afterword is a cherry on top.    Rejection by Juan Carlos Valdeon Riaño.

At its best, has the sweeping grandeur of time paired with the brevity of life itself to really give the reader something they know is both deeply intimate and unmistakably a public monument.  That ran up until the 70s, at which point Ernaux, who doesn't seem to be one for rehashing what she has already written in other works, cruises a little. But equally, given she is framing this monument of prose with her personal experience as scaffolding to run up and down chiselling away, it makes sense it would drop a little in a period where by her own admission her inner life in all senses was at its nadir, or in its slumber.  The ouroboros is completed when Ernaux ends as she started, with a collection of memories she's chosen to save from time - or at least extend the memory of, the book will go out of print, will decay, will end up in a few national collections which in turn disappear - and with those last few memories collected, understanding the sentiment of this act, both noble and forlorn, I for a moment wept.

This is the best memoir I’ve ever read. The book is unique in that it is told through an impersonal, detached recollection of events, moments. and memories, narrated in the second person. She has an unmatched finger on the pulse of time and seamlessly weaves common themes about womanhood, time, development of self, politics, and modernity through fragments of things — moments, objects, events, people — that alone may have seemed unremarkable. She has a perspective on the world similar to Didion and writes with the same detached truthfulness.  This is so fun to reflect on books with this app!!!! So exciting

My own review of this book surprises me. In many ways I dragged my feet reading this. Ernaux’s prose (translated by Alison L. Strayer) felt like clockwork, slow and fast depending on how you tracked it. At time it was so rooted in French politics I felt I had no idea what was happening. And yet other times I felt so connected to Ernaux it felt like we shared the same mind since girlhood. Yet in the end I sped through the final 50 pages and was ready to start this novel all over again. It’s not a typical story and reminds me of a novel version of Boyhood. At times it’s just told through images, history, a collective “we.” At other times it explores the concept of memory, age, and the many different selves we all live and know one day. Somehow it captures the many phases we all feel, the points of originality, how we’ll never grow up, even if we know we will. I imagine if I read this book at 60 I’d have the same relationship to it I do now, just with the ever evolving context of outgrowing previous selves. We’re all the same this way, hence AE writing the book as a collective “we” and also a distant examination of “she,” AE, and the imperfection of memory.  “All the images will disappear…save something from the time where we will never be again.”

This book is not just a work of remembrance in the usual sense with an objective of putting a life into a story to create an explanation of self. Annie goes within herself to retrieve the world, the memory and imagination of its bygone days, grasp the changes in ideas, beliefs, and sensibility, the transformation of the French society and the subjects she has seen. The book's last line summarises it's purpose well, to save something from the time where we will never be again.

Many people seem to be comparing with Maupassant's Une Vie, which she does indeed mention at one point as a possible model, but to me this rather gorgeous book comes across more as an early twenty-first century feminist retelling of Proust.  I know what you're going to say: Proust is two and a half thousand pages long, Les Années is just two hundred and fifty. I'm not denying that that's a valid objection. Though, just possibly, it might also tell us something about the differences between men and women. ____________________  Now that I knew what the book was about, I had to read it again. The last pages, when she finally manages to find her voice and become an author, are perhaps even more moving than the corresponding ones in Le Temps retrouvé. As is her take on recapturing the past: rather than Proust's miraculous and slightly implausible revelations, it is a prosaic and credible process of painful, incomplete stitching together, which somehow still manages to create something wonderful and ineffable.  This is an extraordinary novel.

Growing old is a strange and bewildering thing. I know very little about the French political and cultural era Ernaux dwells on, but reading this I was as quietly alienated by the arrival of our familiar present as she seemed to be. Her memories of a different world are somehow intoxicating.  The Years is full of lovely little observations - my copy is absolutely full of highlights. And the lack of any obvious structure (there's no chapters, no climaxes, no single event with any enormous thematic weight) gives it a surprisingly gentle sense of flow, as time rolls by and everything slowly evolves. We get the sense that Ernaux, like all of us, arrived in the middle of proceedings and was shaped by them without having any say in events, then left without her world completing any kind of neat narrative arc. There's an unaffected humility in it.  I imagine most readers under the age of 30 wonder how their own version of this might look.

The German audio drama of Ernaux' books is a vibrant collage of images and memories, a collage less of her own life but of a whole society. In it, it is possible to see many of the big -isms in a time they too were small, capitalism, consumerism, feminism. It is a tender work, a collective wallowing, not without nostalgia and pride. Quite masterful!

review": My first experience reading Ernaux, who was a new writer to me when her Nobel Prize win was announced last year. I would emphatically recommend this, what is said to be her best work, as well-worth the read (I intend to read more of her work which has been translated into English) especially to anyone looking for a new take on a perennial theme of world literature: representations of memory and the past.  Like Proust, her main focus in this work is the recapturing and memorializing of fleeting moments of the past, but unlike her compatriot, Ernaux’s narrative is exaggeratedly (even stubbornly) discrete, rather than one continuous act of recollection. Several of the memory-sequences are seemingly written literally as snapshots of specific moments which in the writing become absorbed into a collective, national or perhaps even a “democratized” history, an aspect further underscored by Ernaux’s choice to write from the third person as well as with a collective “we”, rather than merely as a first-person “I”.  At times Ernaux assumes a slightly more omniscient, definitively historical stance, denoting the passage of time in the naming of cultural movements, fads and significant landmarks in French collective history, events experienced in one form or another by an entire generation of men and women. The result is a moving, nuanced, free-associative memoir of 20th century life that is both personal (i.e. subjective) and political (i.e. collective), one wherein a single life is refracted through a broader social context and thus shaped, in turn, by life itself.

Annie Ernaux‘s ‘Die Jahre’ is an incredible document of its and our time. Ernaux chronicles the life of a young woman (supposedly herself), structured by photographs of her growing from child, into teen, young woman, wife, (divorced) mother, grandmother, and everything in between. Through her life we get to live through a small portion of France’s history, spanning the post-war years up until and slightly beyond the turn of the 21st century. The text’s most striking quality lies in its ability to show the shifts in paradigms and the needed adaptability of the people living through these shifts. From political leadership, anti-war protests, women’s rights activism, to questions of motherhood, sexual freedom, and xenophobia, Ernaux talks us along through it all. While addressing huge topics from a small, individual standpoint, the narration never seems to claim an exhaustive picture of the times it describes. Beautifully, we see the world and it’s symptoms through the lens of the quotidian, the personal.

The experience of reading this book is like letting a river flow over you. It is an epic tapestry of the history happening around mundane ordinary people who inhabit typical trends of their times. They grow up, they marry, they have children, they quarrel, they divorce, and we learn the experience of Everywoman through the flow of history and collective responses to extraordinary events such as the destruction of the World Trade Center. That old quester struggle to answer, “Where were you when…?” Makes the poignant point about how much it matters and it doesn’t. But the individual who can construct a narrative seems to matter very much as is always the case in Annie Ernaux’s work. I don’t know if this review spoils it for a reader, but this is not to everyone’s taste. But it is to mine.

Ernaux’s poetic remembrance of her life warps time in a way that makes you become highly aware of the light all around you, and each passing second. This made me think about the mysterious power of memory and its ability to transport us to both past and future - a power Ernaux evokes through words and shares with the reader.  Sometimes you get a chance to pause and reflect, but mostly there is the busyness of living. After a lifetime of yearning to write this book, Ernaux looks back and tries to capture something of her essence in the act of living. The search for herself through the years and in each experience is poignant and out of reach, so she ties her life to the story of the world. It made me more cognizant of my own existence in this specific time period, how my being is intimately impacted by this moment in history.  This is quite a fun way to travel through 20th century French history. All of this hit harder since I’m currently studying French history. It is striking that because so many events are simply referenced, I imagine a lot of the story that unfolds therefore depends heavily on the reader’s own association of events.  Annie Erneaux and Patti Smith share an ability to use language to capture something magical about memory, a magic that transforms the current moment. It feels like a precious gift.

I enjoyed this book, but did not find it as compelling as I expected, considering its big reputation (Nobel Prize). It is really a stream of consciousness reflection on the life of a French woman growing up in the wake of WWII, right on through to recent times. Having always been a keen reader of world and political news, many of the events and names are familiar, Dien Bien Phu, Algeria, DeGaulle, Giscard d”Etaing and so on. Ernaux also chronicles the changes in French life, including the rise of consumerism and the declining authority of the Catholic Church.  The recollections do have that musing quality of Sebald, which Ernaux has been compared to, and The Years does have a mix of memory and history recounted in a very personal manner. But the material in The Years comes in snippets rather than organized with cohesive chapters, as Sebald did with little chapters. Sebald also made great use of photographs that illustrated many of his recollections, while Ernaux often describes a photograph and what the memory means to her. I wish she had included the pictures. Perhaps this book would be better as an audio book, in which the memories could glide through the reader’s ears, but I found much of the book to feel similar, page after page of short, seemingly disconnected recollections. I enjoyed the ending very much, where the author did seem to me to impose a more complete form to her memories.

I'm not that fond of auto-fiction or memoir, and this book seemed to me like an endless spool of both. Our narrator is solipsistic in the extreme, but that does not keep her from making some insightful observations about consumerism and the march away from traditional family values, both of which come with our modern times. Still, to me the book was tiresome, with a plot that had no real beginning, middle or end, or even many events marked by human interaction. On and on with the observations of one human being, which, while interesting at times, was not sufficiently compelling to be worth remembering.  Oh, and I'm kind of stunned that it won the Nobel Prize for Literature . . .

In which she switches modes completely and writes a montage retrospective.  I was expecting to like this better…I would place Happening, A Man’s Place, A Woman’s Story, and I remain in Darkness ahead of it in my rankings…at least right now.  I was thinking that there’s a charitable and less charitable reading of this book…and then she did that thing near the end that she sometimes does where she talks about her writing project directly—and that threw a little bit of a wrench into my interpretation.  The charitable: She switches between points of view with fluidity—between she and we. She doesn’t do “I” here, as in other narratives. How to interpret this “we?” There’s a sense that the “she” is the historical she, her self at that unique time completely immersed in being (ready to hand?) and the “we” expresses when her reflective self, the continuous persistence of being self (the present at hand?) is being described in conjunction with that historical self, when they are united (maybe when she has journal entries to work from?). Ernaux knows that there’s a continuous passing out of being, a destruction of that unique self at that particular time that cannot ever be recaptured living doubled with the continuously aging constant self of the ever-present—and her stratagem is to record her life in writing so that she can go back and forensically reconstruct her former selves. She denies that there is any knowledge that is produced in this project—and she’s aware of its narcissism.  The less charitable: The “we” is just the collective an d she’s trying to speak for her generation. In this text, this POV is a bit problematic—and as “she” and “we” gets older they begin to sound avuncular (is there a female version of this word? avancular?)  Ernaux’s confrontation: Toward the end, Ernaux pretty much recognizes that both are happening—though she doesn’t really focus on my charitable reading. Instead she seems to want to claim that the representation of the collective can only happen through the particular.  Are there people that identify with her experience? Sure.  To my thinking, her argument is unsatisfactory.  This work is definitely best enjoyed last if you’re doing an Ernaux reading project. She even writes a little about her children and experiences as a mother—something that she doesn’t do in any of the other’s that I’ve read.  After reading 12 of her works, I’m tempted to say something intentionally provocative, such as Ernaux is mid, actually. But, though her project didn’t do that much for me, I appreciate what she’s done. Ernaux is a magnificent writer. This is a kind of biography that I have never seen before, almost hallucinatory, tied to events and the world around her. Her journey from post WW II to about 2006 closely resembles the American Baby Boom generation with the Sexual Revolution, collapse of faith, and acceptance of consumerism as the highest good. I certainly do not think like her and find many of her beliefs repulsive, but this should be a great historical document in the far future when people want to understand what a life was like during the massive transitions of the past 80 years. The reality that all of us will soon be totally forgotten is melancholy and you can feel that ache in her writing. Well done.

I understand that this book is a roman a clef: an autobiographical novel. The 82-year-old Ernaux has novelized the story of her life, and she has done it in an experimental form.  The novel is written chronologically but less in the form of a traditional narrative than in of a succession of moments or impressions. Ernaux alternates personal moments with historical moments as a way of making the book about her generation rather than just about her. She starts with her impoverished childhood in Normandy in the years immediately after World War Two, and her memories of her parents and grandparents talking about the recent World Wars, always using we" and "us" as if the hardships of war had turned individuals into a collective. One of the striking things about the book is the contrast between these conversations and the conversations that take place around her own table many years later when she is a grandmother. Her children and grandchildren talk mostly in the first person singular

Wow. This book is truly a magnum opus, and I’m still in awe at the ingenuity and creativity of the idea of a collective impersonal autobiography, at its masterful execution through careful word choice and breathless, winding sentences (also on the part of the translator, who successfully conveyed elements intrinsic to the French language like the pronoun ‘on’). Ernaux somehow managed to tell the story of her own life and of an entire generation at once, expertly zooming in and out and back again. One can only hope to mirror a project of this scale.  The only reason I give it four stars instead of five is because it could become a bit dull or monotonous to read at times, but that is a small price to pay for the brilliant reflection of the incessant passage of time without chapter breaks or clear transition points. I also think it would be less exciting or easy to understand for those unfamiliar with French history and culture.  This really is amazing. I adore books that address the phenomenons of memory and youth slipping away, and the “palimpsest self” finally put words to a sensation that I’ve increasingly felt over the past year. It was a sobering touch to include detailed descriptions of and introspection about photographs/videos of the author throughout the years. I also enjoyed the interspersed lists throughout.  SUCH a groundbreaking idea.

The Years by Annie Ernaux – it spans from Ernaux’s birth in 1940 to 2006. It is not a biography in a traditional sense as it is told as ‘we’ but Ernaux tells both her story and that of her generation. Probably one of the most compelling books I’ve read year-to-date. It’s very existential…the main protagonist is our relationship with time, and how it protracts and shortens periods of life. You feel all of our petty reactivity to and complete intractableness of the current of time. There’s also something soothing about the authenticity of her account, she admits in the end its fallibility, but what seemed most appealing to me was the grace of watching it all unfold. This is a story where the characters are really trapped in the amber of the present, which is a really trite thing to say, but it worked for me. Maybe I’ll always be waiting to grow up—and the years will slip by with a quiet force.

I read this book while travelling around France and I - like so many others - have sufficiently become smitten with the writings of Annie Ernaux.  The Years (as the title insinuates) spans over decades, starting in the early 1940’s and ending in the late 2000’s connecting the realms of Ernaux’s rich inner life and the outside world with all that it entails; politics, revolution, immigration, technology, economy - the list goes on.  The book moves in a chronological order, starting at the birth of the author and moving through childhood, youth, parenthood and menopause. I found myself initially being drawn to Ernaux’s musings about girlhood and the madness of being a young woman - it felt eerily relatable as a woman in my early 20’s despite Ernaux’s girlhood ending about 60 years ago…  “‘I am a will and a desire.’ She does not say for what.”  As the book progressed into realms I have no way of relating to, it continued to capture my undivided attention. In thinking about why I was so enraptured by world events that happened long before my birth or the inner life of a woman going through early motherhood, divorce and the life that comes after, I realised that the book itself and what it does - not necessarily the specific story it tells - was the thing that fascinated me so much.  “What matters to her, on the contrary, is to seize this time that comprises her life on Earth at a given period, the time that has coursed through her, the world she has recorded merely by living.”  The documentation of life lived - in the way that Ernaux does it - is something so comforting and life affirming, that this book has automatically wedged itself into one of my favourites. It came to me at the perfect time, and I can’t wait to read it again and again and again.

“All the images will disappear.” Part memoir, part literature, this is one of Ernaux’s longer and more famous works. A series of photographs and videos are used as an outline for the author’s life. Visuals – I wish they had been included – were utilized by the author to “capture the reflection that collective history projects upon the screen of individual memory.” However, it is not merely a personal reflection; the story interweaves essential world events, especially French events, with the author’s life stories. The story begins with a sepia baby photo in the war-torn Normandy village of Yvetot and ends with a photo taken of the sexagenarian author (“This is me = I see no additional signs of aging”), now residing in the quaint Parisian suburb of Cergy. We are transported on a fascinating life journey – both for Annie Ernaux and for society. The author attempts to reclaim and retain history, “the palimpsest sensation” (something reused but bearing traces of the original). Ernaux is an artful archivist, frequently using bullet points to punctuate events. And thus, the purpose of this book, “She is afraid that as she ages her memory will become cloudy and silent.” This fear may have been heightened by the loss of the author’s mother to Alzheimer’s disease. Yet it highlights the reality that we all face: “Everything will be erased in a second . . . we will be nothing but a first name, increasingly faceless, until we vanish into the vast anonymity of a distant generation.” The making of this book prolonged the ephemeral existence of Annie Ernaux – and, in some way, the reader.

I read this book to understand a first hand perception of the events of may 1968 in France but I got so much more out of it. At the end the protagonist says the purpose of this book is ‘to save’ and then she goes on to list these memories and images that mean nothing to anyone other than herself. By putting them on paper they get to exist somewhere other than her mind. This reflects the way that we can become obsessed with certain experiences or memories that linger in our minds- not because they have any significance but because they are defined by our point of view. They are “the images of a moment bathed in a light that is theirs alone”. I relate to this book more than I thought I would because it is written by a woman born in 1940 and I’m a girl born in 2006, but it tells me that time doesn’t change everything, especially how its passing makes you feel.

Ms. Ernaux writes -- during the course of this memoir of her life and the wider context in which she lived it from 1941-2006 -- of her longstanding determination to write a personal history, her evolving concept of what she would like it to be, and how to achieve that project. For me, the end result is a mixed success. The earlier sections, which she surely wrote long after the events they depict, are really luminous and palpable, while the later sections are more routine and almost seem written from a sense of duty to finish. In the book's first pages, she reflects on how much is lost when an individual person dies, and how precious the smallest detail can become as the number of people with whom you share the memory diminishes. So, it should be no surprise that from a distance, it's easier to identify with clarity which personal and societal events and practices really were significant or exemplified a world that would later change and be lost. That perspective is missing, of course, from the years close to the book's publication, but she maintains a similar tone and technique for those sections, and it's not as effective. (I also have to admit that because she belongs to my mother's generation, I also had some 'ok, Boomer' reactions as a reader that may have colored my perceptions.) Still, I look forward to reading more of her work.

In Annie Ernaux’s The Years she writes of wanting the book to “capture the reflection that collective history projects upon the screen of individual memory,” and I think it succeeds marvelously at that. What I found most interesting was the way she tracks the shift from a collective social identity to a singular, consumable identity in the decades between the end of World War II and the years after 9/11. But she also traces the way our sense of self (selves?) shift, or are replaced, as we age in a way that resonated with me.

As much as I liked this book, it would have been an even richer reading experience had I understood the copious references to French historical and cultural events Ernaux lists off throughout it. To have spent the time to research all of them would have been a long process. Despite my ignorance of the majority of the references, I enjoyed the scrapbook-like structure of remembrances of France from Ernaux's birth in 1940 into the 2000s, and the combination of personal history (though told with a bit if a distance -- no I" or "me" to be seen) and broader cultural history."

Its a fascinating blend of personal and collective memory, a sequence of political and familial disappointments bargained over and negotiated against the author's endless questioning of what is asked of life. The central player is time, which almost guarantees no satisfactory answer to the multi-scalar question of desire. She sees shadows of herself in the younger generation she helped to raise; she sees shadows of herself in the older generation that raised her. And yet, she experiences a felt removal from both impressions, flighty as they may seem. It is difficult to ever truly know oneself. I'm not quite as old as the author at the time of her writing this, but the reflections suggest that time may not help so much with settling one's inventory of the soul. Of course, the opposite may be just as true. This isn't a sketch of the author as an individual so much as a particular timeline associated with a shared history. In her arrangement of events, its impossible to separate the individual from the nation. Very provocative, moving, consuming, affective... knowing that she'll lose her images, she takes part in this act of sharing. Met with her images, I feel that I've lost my words.

This was my first attempt to Annie Ernaux’s body of work. In the back cover of this edition it states that Ernaux invented a new genre, the “collective autobiography”. “The Years” are exactly that, a chronological and continuous discourse of the author’s life, never told in the first person, but instead detached of the self and described through the experiences of abstracts groups, the parents, the teenagers, the students, etc. … Even when the author is referring to herself it is as if she is describing another woman. As much as I acknowledge the originality of all the above, this book did not quite “click” for me, and I felt mostly disengaged throughout. Can’t quite really pinpoint why, perhaps I did not feel connected to Ernaux’s life as a “character” or the fact that I am not the Francophile and innumerous cultural references may have been lost on me. I do not challenge at all that Ernaux is Nobel prize material, and I do recognize the innovation and the new form she created, but this book, for me, was not a hugely pleasurable experience.

This book reminded me of my days in France, the travels and misty winter mornings. This book seems a passage of time weaving personal recollections and collective memories to offer a profound exploration of French identity.  While the book initially appeared to me as a culture centric ( to french readers) but there are passages that stands for cross-cultural such as norms for women.  The Years is primarily focused on France because Ernaux crafts her memoir around a specific historical context, capturing the evolution of French society from the 1940s to 1986 and 2000s. By intertwining her own memories with broader cultural milestones—such as the Algerian War for independence, May 1968 protests, and the AIDS epidemic—Ernaux provides a panoramic view of French history and a clear sense of its influence on identity formation.  I liked how she narrated time through photographs from childhood to adulthood. Each photo contains a story and memory. But frankly speaking I would not recommend this strongly because focus was much on french. For me, it brought back memories.  A pov is presented through passages that it is a universal human desire to make sense of our pasts and construct our individual identities amidst societal changes. And it places a strong emphasis on the female experience, making it an essential read for women seeking validation and empowerment through their own recollections.  Ernaux captures the challenges, triumphs, and everyday experiences that shape a woman's life. And I think a few passages in book motivated me to read it. Ofcourse author is Nobel prize winner 🏆. So I wanted to read to know more.  Read it if you want to amass the understanding of another culture.

This book is a beautifully written autobiography in which the author talks about her life from the point of view of an outside observer. It is mainly a book of social and political events and the author's observation of them rather than an autobiography of the author's inner most feelings. I felt as if the author deliberately played down her feelings to avoid the pain of their sharp realization. For instance Ernaux does not talk much of her husband, children or lovers or even give them names. I enjoyed reading about events and social commentary before and during World War II as that was before I was born and I hadn't realized the scarcity of things then. It was also interesting to read of the decades through I which lived from a French woman's view as opposed to an American's view. All in all, great writing.

The ebb and flow of this book walked me through the decades of the author's life - years that almost parallel my own.I easily imagined the photos the author may have been viewing - each triggered a story, a narrative that included a global influence and how it influenced her own experience. I am enamored of old photos, so I easily conjured up images described by the author. I read most of this compelling book in one sitting. I am left eager to read more of her writing. I dog-eared so many page to refer back to. I will be revisiting this book for some time. I do not think it will be embraced by all who pick it up, but it most certainly spoke to me. - Ginn

Annie Ernaux, a recent Noble Laureate and one of her generation's most acclaimed French writers, decided she wanted to put half a century into a novel. Bold, no? The Years, told in unusual second-person style that mixes the personal with the universal is a piercingly wise memoiristic depiction of 66 years of life in France. It's a Proustian act of revelation and creative memory--locating the emotional and cultural moments that loom large across decades and a poignant grappling with why those moments matter.  Ernaux has a preternatural ability to distill difficult concepts pertaining to the emotional rawness of major events--Paris student riots, the premiere of Breathless, 9/11--into the distinctly personal. It's an act of literary transfiguration I've not seen--the universal into the personal until it's once again universal. Her aphoristic stylings lend beauty to mundane moments as well as perspective into events so large we can barely even comprehend her scale. In some ways, it rearragnes how we think about the world.  I think the most powerful aspect of the novel is how it encourages you to think about your own life and your own relation to history. I found myself trawling back through childhood, first loves, early passions, and attempting to formulate what they meant to me and my relation to the world. How have the major events of my life--9/11, The Arab spring, 2016 election, rise of social media--impacted the world in which I live not only on the macro level, but the micro level? Have those tides of history shoved me into a different path or they only things to mention to the youths that I lived through when I'm old? I don't think there are any true answers, but I do think Ernaux's struggle to grapple with what it means to live when we lived and how we lived is one of the truly great questions that make this novel transcendent.

Difficult and depressing. I wish I had read it in French. If you think anything happy could possibly exist between 1941 and 2006, you will not find it in this book. It feels that the bleak announcements we hear in 2023 about climate change, about the various wars, unrest, murders, politics are just echoes of the droning in these pages. The reviews praise the depersonalization of style, but I wish there had been something about the author that allowed me to feel I was reading her memoir. That she refers to herself in the 3rd person heightens the sense that whatever is said doesn't matter, to her, or to any reader. The Chekhov quote at the beginning reminds us indeed, we are worthy of forgetting. Perhaps the José Ortega y Gasset quote lends to deeper probing. All we have is our history

Obvious 5 stars. Literally I want to eat this prose for a meal. It is so condensed, every sentence contains a new, brilliant revelation that no one else could’ve ever thought of. The way that Ernaux can read groups of people and habits and situations and get to the root of how they interact w their context and what they mean on a sociological/personal level???? Genius! To see the world through her eyes! Constant 🤯🤯🤯. Also just baffled (in a great way) by how she incisively nails consumerism, identity politics, shame, etc… things that I thought were so decisively 2022 American but are not at all…  Definitely a slowww read though and one that people born in 2002 in Florida lack the educational context to fully understand (❤️😄😔) . But I kept up as I could, as I was just in love with this idea of a memoir snuggled into a recounting of culture/politics/events in France, which is both objective and subjective at the same time, one person’s experience with time intersecting with something greater, something collective—a History.  —  “Signs of collective change cannot be perceived in the specific features of lives, except, perhaps, in the disgust and fatigue that led thousands of individuals at once to think, in exasperation, “So that’s how it is—nothing will ever change.”  “And we did not age. The things around us didn’t last long enough to grow old, replaced and rehabilitated at lightning speed. Our memory didn’t have time to associate them with moments of existence.”  “With all the intermingling of concepts, it was increasingly difficult to find a phrase of one’s own, the kind that, when silently repeated, helped one live.”
The (French) emperor wears no clothes!

This was absolutely one of the best books I've ever read.  A book where I had to stop at every sentence, re-read, sometimes aloud, sometimes in translation, share it with friends.  A book, which despite being about France and which often had references I didn't get, made me feel at home.  A book that I'm definitely going to read again at some point in the future.  In The Years, Annie Ernaux is telling her own life story in post-WWII France until the early 21st century interwoven with history. Through the passing years we see the change in the little girl growing into a woman and then ageing and we see all the changes France and the world goes through. We see the political and cultural references. We see the political and personal intertwined and inseparable. And things happening today start making more sense.  This is not an autobiography or a memoire. It's telling history in a personal way.  This is a must-read for leftists, for feminists and for those who are interested in the why and the how we got where we are today.

review": It’s very hard for me to rate this book. I feel like I didn’t quite understand all its depths and messages. There were a lot of local and historical references unknown to me. Even so, the way the author writes the narrative, trying to stay objective, but letting her thoughts and emotions subtly and often not so subtly come through gives a life to what could’ve been a boring story about the past. Human insecurities, the everpresent changes and stuggles, the full circle(s) of life are shown in a very subtle but lively and common way.

Capturing life after World War II in France through one woman’s life. Big trends like consumerism, sexual liberation, AIDS, decolonization racial tensions and unemployment coalesce with pictures from the authors life Memory like sexual desire never endse  An erudite work, more essay and history piece than novel. I love Annie Ernaux her writing, but this book is an especially ambitious work that sets out to capture post-World War II France. The Years uses pictures as basis of recollections. From initial family observations and catch phrases that parents use: Limits: don’t ask for the moon or things that cost the earth, be happy with what you have to the desire to grow up as a kid: Nothing is certain except her desire to be grown up. Paris was beauty and power and the big city calls. The post war years are sparse initially, We lived in a scarcity of everything but people are optimistic about what lay ahead: Progress was the bright horizon of everyone’s existence  The narration is detached, and the novel uses a lot of sweeping statements to describe the day and age. At times Ernaux recognises that the perspective used in the book is not universal: The times are not the same for everyone. To be fair there are fun anachronisms captured as well, like arsenic cures against masturbation.  Big societal changes are captured, like youth asking more of their lives and the freedoms they want You ask too much of life and the rise of consumers and tourists: It was the dawning of the society of leisure Growing up as a female is hard (For girls shame lay in wait at every turn), and the way Ernaux writes time definitely seems to go ever faster but all the changes feel less and less impactful to one who has established her life through the rapid succession of decolonization, the advent of consumerism, sexual liberalism, women’s rights, May 1968, AIDS, racial tensions, unemployment. There is disappointment and reflection (As if her only progress in life is of the material kind) and the sense of the end nearing is evident near the end of the book: The infinite ceased to be imaginary  A sweeping book, following both a life and development of a nation, full of observations that one can only have after a life lived and fully experienced.

review": Excellent, as expected

Done reading #The_Years by #Annie_Ernaux: It is a memoir from the perspective of a working class woman from the 1940s of her childhood and the beginning of WWII UNTIL 2006 It offers a deep account of her life from her childhood in Normandy till her present day existence as an established writer in Paris . The scope is wide and traces all the changes in Europe and in France in particular throughout the decades from her own perspective as a working class female . She talks about the gradual collapse of the morality from the late 60s into the 70s and then the 80s and how that transferred into consumerism in the 90s Other themes of the book includes the gain of personal freedom and socioeconomic changes The statements are simple and serve the book well . It is structured as a series of snapshots each focusing on a particular year or period in her life and the events and experiences that shaped her as an individual and as a part of the French society so Each section starts by looking at a dated picture with description of that photograph talKing about the girl she sees in the photograph ( herself) in the third person . Sometimes she runs into WE into the first person plural in a gradual and subtle manner that does not confuse the reader .This first person plural reminds me of another book ( the Buddha in the attic). Throughout we are following the life of a girl that is Annie Ernaux who is trying to piece together her own past along with her social .political and the past of her country .Throughout she reflects on the social ,cultural and political changes that had taken place in France in the course of her lifetime from the aftermath of WWII TILL her present day and the way in which those changes have impacted her own identity and sense of self . We notice that throughout the book we follow Ernaux as she explains themes of class , gender and sexuality reflecting on her own experiences as a working class woman in a predominantly middle class society . She writes about the ways in which her identity has been shaped by her family background , her education and her relationships with men shedding light on some of the most significant political and social changes of the post war era including the rise of consumerism , the decline of traditional social structures and the emergence of new forms of identity and belongings . It is a powerful reflection on memory , identity and the passage of time .she draws from a wide range of sources including family photographs and personal diaries to historical archives and literary texts , books , songs ,radios , tv clips , advertising and news headlines to create a vivid and intimate portraits of her life and times. Her writing is marked by deep nostalgia and loss as she recalls and reflects on the people and places that have come and gone in her life. This is the Annie Ernaux as Annie Ernaux has imagined reconstructed and remembered . It is not her story alone but the intimate details of the French life that shaped society and brought changes It is sensitive and honest , so well written and it was a pleasure reading it …have learned so much in terms of historical events that shaped the world and French society ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Interweaving politics, pop culture, likening the Pope kissing through ground in a time where religion is farcical to throwing panties during a Madonna concert, this was a fun romp through the decades between the 60s to the 2000s. But make no mistake: the aftermath of the wars, the political tensions, the anxieties of the future are very much palpable here, to the point where it becomes not a story of someone's life, but a story of our lives. So much of the world was covered, so much personal feelings explored. It is the perfect example of the slogan the personal is the political" not just in terms of global happenings

review": Never read a book like this before. Ernaux, a teacher from France, writes a memoir of her life from her birth in 1940 through 2007. She uses impersonal pronouns to tell her story (“je collectif.”) most often “we”, as if reporting the collective experience of her generation exclusively through her own experience.  (I’m reminded of what HST said about how the subjective can be closer to the truth than the objective).  Particularly interested to read about how we came to now, how the world has changed since 1940, and the unfolding of the globalized “modern world” in real time, and it’s personal consequences. Gets slow at times and the somewhat frequent discussion of French politics wasn’t particularly interesting to me, but recommend.  Started in a writing class at school in the spring, finished the last third on my phone during a slow day at the distillery.

“There was a need for war, as if people had suffered a lack of events for a long time, coveting the ones they could only experience as television viewers. There was a desire to reconnect with age-old tragedy.”  For Fans Of:  French Ennui Sick burns of the Catholic Church Cherishing your grandmum telling the same story for the 100th time, knowing you won’t have her much longer  Winner of the 2022 Nobel Prize, and the perfect way to dive into Women in Translation month. This is my first Annie Ernaux, and apparently she is the voice of french women and I 100% believe that. ‘The Years’ is unlike anything I’ve ever read - we are not following the life of one author, but the life of the collective female consciousness through 60 years of French history. Ernaux takes us on a roadtrip through the french obsession with sex - sexual desire, sexual liberation, depression because of/in spite of sexual liberation - labor movements, political upheavals, consumerism, communism, and seemingly most-importantly for everyone involved, the legalization of divorce.  She also pushes us to figure out what our generation’s unifying event is. For our great grandparents, at least in Europe and North America, it was WWII. For our grandparents, Vietnam. For our parents, 9/11. What’s ours? Or do we not get a unifying tragedy - are we just bleeding out, to steal a phrase from our generation’s greatest poet, Ms. Swift, from ”death by a thousand cuts?”  The translation by Alison Strayer from the original French is bril, but this is definitely a French book for French folks. Almost like if someone from Croatia tried to read through 60 successive years of Dave Barry’s “Year in Review.” 5 stars for execution, but 3 stars for my personal reading experience.

review": I loved her writing, but not so interested in the years she covers, as I lived through most of them. But her style of writing is excellent.

Excellent experimental project, especially her use of point of view. I found the latter third to be rather sad, a reflection on how our lives become defined by consumerism and headline news instead of our own discoveries, but that is to her point, I guess: much of life as we get older is what happens to us, after we've done what we can to make our individual impressions. This work, I imagine, is Ernaux's way of coming to terms with her aging and of days past, which acts as a reclamation of self in its own right.

I liked « Les années » very much for a simple reason. It seems that through this book I have relived the entire existences of my parents and mine also. The author was born in 1940, 7 years after my own parents. This means that all the postwar stories she relates are similar to what I heard as a kid from my parents. The fact that she lived as an adult through mai 68, de Gaulle, 10 of May 1981,… make the book sounds like if my parents were speaking to me. Covering such a long time period, the book is a catalog of the societal changes and how they have changed us as individuals. One main theme is how time seems to be speeding up and how we are bombarded by more material “stuff”, and still it does not appear to have increased our satisfaction with life! 50 years ago, «…on avait le temps de désirer les choses, la trousse en plastique, les chaussures à semelles de crêpe, la montre en or. Leur possession ne décevait pas. On les offrait à l'admiration des autres. Elles recelaient un mystère et une magie qui ne s'épuisaient pas dans leur contemplation et leur manipulation. Les tournant et les retournant, on continuait d'attendre d'elles on ne savait quoi après les avoir eues.» Whereas now, in the 21st century, « …on passait au lecteur de DVD, à l'appareil photo numérique, au baladeur MP3, à l'ADSL, à l'écran plat, on n'arrêtait pas de passer. Ne plus passer, c'était accepter de vieillir. » In fact, it seems that this acceleration is even making us insensitive to the value of progress; “…le concept même de nouveau disparaîtrait peut-être, comme déjà presque celui de progrès, nous y étions condamnés.» And so, having relived the lives of my parents and my own life in a “fast forward” mode, added to my own personal search for meaning in this world, I share the author feeling of confusion about the sense of it all: “…ses parents dans la petite ville normande, sa mère ôtant sa blouse pour aller au salut le soir, son père remontant du jardin, sa bêche à l'épaule, un monde lent qui continue d'exister, plus irréel qu'un film, loin de celui dont elle fait partie, moderne, cultivé, qui avance, vers quoi, difficile de le dire. » Yes, we are moving forward, but it’s hard to say what’s our destination!
“To save something from the time where we will never be again” p225

I liked it a lot and didn't expect that since it's not your ordinary book with a plot and defined characters. But the avalanche of feelings, emotions, thoughts and portrayals of several generations of people all around the world (with a focus on France) is overwhelming sometimes. Nothing happens and everything happens at the same time. The development (or its history) of humanity since the end of the 2nd world war until contemporary times is presented chronologically and it makes sense. Against this backdrop, photos and videos of a girl/woman during different stages of her life are scattered (is it the writer?), almost mindlessly. You just have to read it to understand.

The Years is a work of remembrance, where the author explores the concept of collective and individual memory through surgically precised prose, capturing the social, political, and cultural evolution of France from the 1940s into the second millennium. A well-written contemplation on the ever-shifting nature of both personal and collective identity.

The books is authentic and raw - more honest than I would currently be capable of.  For ambitious mothers / deep-thinking mothers, or father's supporting mothers this is an important book. Nothing comes for free.  Generally enjoyable, and has made me think - esp. about what growing up female means, and the hyper-sexualisation of women.

I don’t think I’ve ever heard of a book this short being called and epic but THIS IS an epic. Annie Ernaux has perfectly curated a vast array of material based on her life and the political climate around her life experiences into a concise and beautifully written book. There is so much of the author in this book that reading it feels like a highly personal and intimate experience.  I loved Ernaux’s use of descriptions of photographs featuring herself as a framing device that is revisited throughout the book. It consistently reset the pace of the book. A lot of the book is quite submerging due to its emotional and real foundations so you can become sucked into this world. The use of photo descriptions brings you back to an outsider position which is a grounding experience and I think essential to the book.

‘Everything will be erased in a second. The dictionary of words amassed between cradle and deathbed, eliminated. All there will be is silence and no words to say it. Nothing will come out of the open mouth, neither I nor me. Language will continue to put the world into words. In conversation around a holiday table, we will be nothing but a first name, increasingly faceless, until we vanish into the vast anonymity of a distant generation.’  All is mostly good, but I've still not warmed up to it (Ernaux's writing/work) stylistically. I'm reading Typewriters, Bombs, Jellyfish: Essays on the side, and it kind of reminds me of Ernaux's book. I think it's mainly because they discuss and explore similar events in their books. I prefer the way McCarthy's book is structured (and I just simply enjoy the content a little more as well; more variation/etc.). It's more organised, and I just like it more 'stylistically'. Maybe I'll have to read a couple more Ernaux(es?). A more thorough RTC later, maybe.  Also, thank you to S. for encouraging me to read this! I'm really glad I did.   ‘But we did want to remember the World Cup. It was said that people would have willingly relived the weeks of waiting around TV sets in the silent cities where pizza Mobylettes buzzed back and forth; the weeks that led match by match to that Sunday and that moment when, amidst the clamour and ecstasy we knew that, having won, we could all die happy, die together (except that it was the exact opposite of death), rediscover the great surrender to one sole desire, one image, one story. Those were dazzling days, whose derisory remains fluttered for months from the walls of the Métro: posters of Zidane for Eau d’Évian and Leader Price budget grocery.’  ‘The moon, when we looked up at night, shone fixedly on billions of people, a world whose vastness and teeming activity we could feel inside. Consciousness stretched across the total space of the planet toward other galaxies. The infinite ceased to be imaginary. That is why it seemed inconceivable that one day we would die.’

Winner of the 2022 Nobel Prize in Literature, Annie Ernaux writes a memoir and personal history of her life and France from 1940 to the present. It is not written in first person, instead the writer does everything in the 3rd person. Some sections are anchored by descriptions of photos of the author and her family.

On how individual memmory intertwines with colective memmory. On how some moments make you feel like a part of something bigger, common. On how we are all part of a generation that experiences its given set of years very differently. On how these years will never repeat themselves.
I thought this was an innovative and fascinating way to construct a memoir. The overlaps (and disjunctions) of my personal development alongside world events were nteresting.

What a gem of a book.  Ernaux has written an unconventional auto-biography, where she is the subject (written about in third person), but she shares the spotlight with her generational and cultural cohort, with many passages written about ‘we’.  “We had time to desire things, plastic pencil cases, crepe-doled shoes, gold watches. Their possession did not disappoint. We held them up to the admiration of others.”  I missed out on 2/3 of the French cultural references, not being of her generation, or French. But that didn’t matter - so many of her references are just human, very relatable.  “We laughed at the terror of the wealthy who hightailed it to Switzerland to stash their money, and condescendingly reassured the secretaries who were convinced their apartments would be seized for nationalized housing. The attack against John Paul II, shot by a Turk, came at a bad time. We’d forget all about it.”  A fascinating way to mark the generational and social changes since WWII, from the perspective of a now aged progressive Boomer. . In the last few pages she reflects on aging, the passage of time and generations in a way I’ve never read before. She’s not tender or brutal about it - just honest.

Ernaux takes us through the years from the early 50s to the present time. She used France as a model, but much could be applicable to other parts of the Western world. It started with her childhood just after the war when outdoor toilets were common as well as shortages and a strict moral code in destroyed cities, villages, and countryside. Through examples of her life and commentary, she took us on the voyage towards consumerism, technological advances, free love, and the rise of the left and the right. Although I didn't warm to the book, it was a compelling read.

To exist is to drink oneself without thirst.  Reading The Years is like watching one of those short videos, showing the evolution of dance or fashion throughout history.  Our memory is outside us, in a rainy breath of time.  We read the book, as if we are looking at photos and scenes, captured successively in different stages of Annie’s life; as if we are reading news reports about social, economic and political events; events which made an impression on her external and internal self.  Like sexual desire, memory never stops. It pairs the dead with the living, real with imaginary beings, dreams with history.  The Years is freeze-frames of Annie’s memories and her existence; a memoir of one and all.  She begins a novel in which images past and present, her dreams at night and visions of the future, alternate with an “I” who is her double, detached from herself.  There are no chapters, but at the beginning of each decade, she offers and describes a photograph of herself, as a little baby, a child, a teenager, etc. Of course as she always does, she talks about herself in third person.  There is no “I” in what she views as a sort of impersonal autobiography. There is only “one” and “we,” as if now it were her turn to tell the story of the time-before.  This is a writing project of a woman who has lived between 1940 and today, convinced that she has no “personality”.  She will go within herself only to retrieve the world, the memory and imagination of its bygone days, grasp the changes in ideas, beliefs, and sensibility, the transformation of people and the subject that she has seen.  She wants to save everything that has been part of her life; she wants to save her “circumstance”.  The distance that separates past from present can be measured perhaps by the light that spills across the ground between shadows, slips over faces, outlines the folds of a dress- by the twilight clarity of a black-and-white photo, no matter what time it is taken.  She wants to hunt down the sensations inside of her; sensations like the ones that make her write.  Everything will be erased in a second. The dictionary of words amassed between cradle and deathbed, eliminated. All there will be is silence and no words to say it. Nothing will come out of the open mouth, neither I nor me. Language will continue to put the world into words. In conversation around a holiday table, we will be nothing but a first name, increasingly faceless, until we vanish into the vast anonymity of a distant generation.

Annie Ernaux is very, very good at what she does. Her prose is beautiful and sweeping, and this book is filled with reflective insights about the process of aging, collective experience, and social history. Unfortunately, as a stinky American, there were a lot of French history and politics specific details that were lost on me. I found those sections harder to read, and later periods where history and memory became more globalized to be more familiar and thus resonant. That's not a flaw of the book itself--I'm not American enough to demand that the French author writing for a French audience write things that I understand, but it did detract from how much I might've enjoyed reading this. Perhaps to be revisited in the future, if I ever have any interest/inquiry into 1900s French sociopolitical history.

This one seemed to take me eons to finish. But I’m very happy it turned out this way. An incredible book, however… incredible in the way that you come to see with time. Perhaps like a cup of tea that never immediately overwhelms you but is laden with deep, comforting, rich, and insightful layers. I left this book sitting for quite some time before coming back to it and finishing. And this is when things really took off. At this point, I had uncovered the delight and ingenuity of Ernaux’s structure. Which left me seeping into the prose. Again, much like one can seep into a good cup of tea. The Years (Noble Prize, maybe for freshness, its title lifted from Virginia Woolf) is a compelling long letter, reporting on a well-spent life, beginning in 1941. A non-stop, almost run-on compilation, from a journal and a box of photos. Written to whom, reporting to whom? Someone senior, close but not intimate, attentive but not judgmental, a brother? Grandmother? Does that person now (since Woolf) expect not only a woman’s personal, family and meteorological experiences in an autobiography, but its political and economic encounters as well? When you write your story honestly, do you write it to the person who turns out to be your god? Is it your last elevator pitch?

Her stature as Nobel Prize Winner of Literature in 2022 was well appointed and deserved.

Ernaux uses 'we' throughout this book. This is a collective history, and yet a very personal one. It's particularly weird when talking about the reasons why 'we' the women are considering divorce. The personal, political and social run into one another throughout and cannot be separated.    Occasionally, the reader is invited to observe 'she' a woman in a photo, not directly identified as the narrator. 'She' is on her family holiday.   Then there's a shift part way through, the writing still refers to 'she' but the nostalgia reveals that this 'she' is much closer to the person writing. She remembers different rooms she has slept in. 'She would like to assemble these multiple images of herself, separate and discordant, thread them together with the story of her existence... an existence singular but also merged with the movements of a generation.' From here onwards the narrative of this generation is also threaded with the story of how 'she' became the author of this book.    It is a tricky read, but fascinating. One of the things I found most powerful - and most risky - was the way 'we' expresses racism and prejudice starkly and without comment. It was an uncomfortable read. An author would normally say that she no longer thinks these things, and would cast judgement on them. Instead Ernaux implicates herself and her whole generation, the whole mileau, in the shitty things people thought and said at the time. It feels quite radical, we're often so determined to forget how prejudice we once were, Ernaux isn't letting people get away with it.   It's the story of a culture growing more and more individualist, but the plural with which it's told, shows just how flimsy this belief in our individualism is.

The Years is an amazing mix of memoir and an existentialist diary that focuses on memory and images, which stimulate memories both personal and the vicarious memories of others.  French author Annie Ernaux shares her memories and images from her birth to when she's 66. Her story includes clips of her life as part of events and trends that occurred in France and elsewhere until 2007. It compromises self-reflection as well as how she perceived what happened around her: politics, wars, fads, books, music, films, materialism. It's a look at a life lived and one that grapples with an unimaginable future that ends with death when memory ends.  This book may not appeal to readers who haven't lived in France or Europe, especially during the years she covers. If I hadn't lived in Europe and visited France and Paris during part of the time frame of Ernaux's book. Much of what she describes would have not resonated with me. That said, I recommend reading it anyway.

review": Brilliant, I loved this as a student who takes a course in modern French history.

This book is very focused on political and cultural changes from pre-WW2 to 2008. As the afterword describes, the changes are conveyed via the effect they have on an individual, though Ernaux's writing blurs the line between writing about herself vs. writing about a cohort of peers.  This study really scratches an itch for me; it's weirdly comforting to see the failures of May 1968 (which I guess is like a more serious French version of American hippies / Woodstock people?) traced to the disengagement and disappointment I feel with politics today.  The one big downside is that it's very French-focused. This lead me to some good new wikipedia articles, but made it a bit difficult to weigh the experiences of her life with my understanding of recent American history.  Throughout, there's a touching undercurrent of emotion, where through describing pictures of herself from her past and the images that are preserved in her memory, Ernaux grounds the impersonal set of events within her memory and experience.  All in all, really liked this. Probably would've loved it if I was from France.

The web was the royal road for the remembrance of things past. Archives and all the old things that we'd never even imagined being able to find again arrived with no delay. Memory became inexhaustible, but the depth of time, its sensation conveyed through odor and the yellowing of paper, bent-back pages, paragraphs underscored in an unknown hand, had disappeared. Here we dwelled in the infinite present.  Our photographs and films-filed by date and viewed on screen, one after the other without a pause- were pervaded by the light of a time that was unique, no matter how diverse the scenes and landscapes. Another form of past came into being, fluid, with little real memory content. There were too many images for us to stop at each and recall the circumstances in which they were taken. Inside them, we lived a near weightless transfigured existence. The signs of our existence multiplied and put an end to the sensation of time marching on.

What a profound work of literature. Annie Ernaux layers her personal history over the history of the latter part of the 20th century. We see, think, and feel as she does during and after the liberation of France in 1945, experience the excitement/freedom of the sexual revolution of the 70s, the confusion of the technological advancements during the 80s-2000s. Political, economical, and social events are brought in and out of focus through her lens.  We simultaneously learn about Ernaux’s life as a student, wife/ex-wife, mother, author, occasional lover, pet owner (this had me bawling). At the end of this book, I was almost overwhelmed by the depth and breadth of human experience and also grateful for the lens Ernaux has provided to the world. I definitely want to keep a copy of this close by for reference.

I found this book puzzling - it didn't quite move me emotionally; intellectually, I can appreciate Ernaux's vast capability to track historical events throughout her life, and it's inspired me to consider keeping a journal of my own. I wonder if not being French and being unable to understand all these references is a reason why I've been handicapped, or if a great book (as this one is) should be able to reach me regardless.  Overall themes of Ernaux's are stretching beyond the personal I" to situate herself (and women's lives) within the broader sociopolitical collective; the consumerization of society (contrast her rural upbringing with her urban adulthood)

This has a vivid record of how France is like after World War II. It also mention facts such as the child death rate was pretty high previously, so it is normal for families to have 8 to 10 children, and maybe half survive. It also give descriptions of how schools was like how people pursue fashion and so on.

It’s as if Ernaux has peered intently at life for decades and has figured out exactly how to translate how time, memory and zeitgeist work in writing. The effects of simply choosing ‘we’ over ‘I’ are far reaching and profound.

There is no book like this one for the sensation of hurtling through time. Ingenious and transporting in its first person plural, its third person, its assertions and continuous discontinuities. Much to learn, here.  “The future is too immense for her to imagine. It will happen, that’s all.” (Annie Ernaux, The Years, 53)  “The increasingly rapid arrival of new things drove the past away. People did not question their usefulness, they just wanted to possess them and suffered when they didn’t earn enough to buy them outright.” (Ernaux, 83)  “She feels she has deviated from her former goals, as if her only progress in life were of the material kind. ‘I’m afraid of settling into this quiet and comfortable life, and afraid to have lived without being aware of it.’ Just as she makes this observation, she knows she isn’t ready to give up the things this diary never includes, the living-together, the shared intimacy, the apartment…” (Ernaux, 93)  “Now, everything once considered normal had become the object of scrutiny.” (Ernaux, 101)  “The discourse of pleasure reigned supreme. You had to feel pleasure while reading, writing, taking a bath, defecating. It was the alpha and the omega of human activities.” (Ernaux, 104)  “People were soothed by the arrival of the new. The certainty of continuous progress removed the desire to imagine it. New objects were no longer met with wonder or anxiety, but welcomed as additions to individual freedom and pleasure.” (Ernaux 141)  “With the Walkman, for the first time music entered the body. We could live inside music, walled off from the world.” (Ernaux, 142)  “Identity, which until then had meant nothing but a card in one’s wallet with a photo glued onto it, became an overriding concern. No one knew exactly what it entailed. Whatever the case, it was something you needed to have, rediscover, assume, assert, express—a supreme and precious commodity.” (Ernaux, 145)  “Children, especially boys, had trouble leaving the family home with its well-stocked fridge, washed and folded clothes, and background hum of childhood. They made love in all innocence in the room next to ours. They settled into a protracted youth; the world wasn’t waiting for them. And by continuing to feed and care about them, we lived in a time that stretched back uninterrupted to their childhood.” (Ernaux, 165)  “And we did not age. The things around us didn’t last long enough to grow old, replaced and rehabilitated at lightning speed. Our memory didn’t have time to associate them with moments of existence.” (Ernaux, 188)  “She’s given up trying to deduce this form that is able to contain her life from the sensation she has on the beach with her eyes closed or in a hotel room, that sense of replicating herself and physically existing in several places she’s known over her life, and thus attaining a palimpsest time.” (Ernaux, 226)  “It will be a slippery narrative composed in an unremitting continuous tense, absolute, devouring the present as it goes, all the way to the final image of a life.” (Ernaux, 229)  “In the old days, when she tried to write in her student room, she yearned to find an unknown language that would unveil mysterious things, in the way of a clairvoyant. She also imagined the finished book as a revelation to others of her innermost being, a superior achievement, a king of glory.” (Ernaux, 229)

review": Original and excellent.

I strongly recommend this sweeping memoir by Nobel Laureate Annie Ernaux. It covers the period from 1940 through 2006. Set in France, it touches on the most arresting cultural, social and political turning points for entire generations. Thoroughly relatable for anyone alive today and perplexed by the rapid change to which we have all had to adapt.  It is also a sort of feminist testament from a woman who lived through a monumental revolution in women's rights throughout her lifetime. It is sad to see some recent setbacks to those rights in the United States. And while she does not talk about such legislation in the USA, a value of this book is how it triggers one's own memory and understanding of year's past.  Finally, while it was published in 2008, it manages to stay fresh and contemporary thanks to its very up to date commentary on our world's digital transition which has been several decades in the making.

Very unique and powerful. The prose is interesting in that while this book is autobiographical, it is presented in a way that comments on and describes the culture and societal dynamics surrounding the author through her life; spanning from the 1940s up to the 2000s in France, written in third-person. The author does this through her own perspective. In doing so, the author both writes about her own personal experiences as well as that of society as a whole. The book discusses various themes of feminism, romantic/familial relationships, politics, philosophies etc and how they have morphed through the 20th century and into the 21st. I have never read a book quite like it.

I struggled with this book, it’s literally “not for me.” There’s a lot of great writing, but if you don’t know a lot about French history/societal history from the 20th century, it’s hard to keep up with the constant unexplained references, even with the footnotes. The overall effect of the first person plural and sentence structure and historical references is that this book is an extended litany, broken up by a few scenes. I found the first and last chapters amazing. In the middle, I had to push myself to keep going and get through the monotony of the litany (which, I suppose, in some part, gets at an effect she wanted of time passing across a lifetime…). The translators note at the end was fascinating — some stuff that I didn’t like about the book was AE’s chosen style, some was a product of translation and the limitations of English vs. French. It made me wish I knew enough history and French to read this book in the original version, to really appreciate the ideas and experimental form of this book.

I keep thinking about the conceptual brilliance of this book. The notion of multiple selves, threaded together with the story of her existence." The way individual memory shapes and is shaped by cultural signifiers and historical/political events to form a "common time

This was one of my favorite reads of the year. It’s is a pseudo memoir, spanning the time from 1941 to 2006, written both as a personal memoir while also the story of the world around the character, charting the social, political, and technological changes.. Annie Ernaux won the 2022 Nobel Prize in Literature, and The Years is considered by many her magnum opus.  The writer’s self comes in and out of the narrative - sometimes she’s not there at all, only time and history. She pops in using we or they or one, but we recognize her as both a singular person and a person of her city, Paris, and generation. Time is marked by big events like a railway strike in 1953 and the fall of Dien Bien Phu in 1954. We read of fighting in Algeria, bit international events like the the building of the Berlin Wall, the Cuban missile crisis, JFK’s assassination, Mao, the Beatles. The contextualization of life with history is jarring - proof of relative time. Sections of the story are introduced by photos, and later videos of a girl and her family, as if someone is flipping through an old album. It was unique and so beautifully written. I looked forward to reading this every day.  The writer/character describes when she first has the idea for what will become this book, after herd divorce: Because in her refound solitude she discovers thoughts and feelings that married life had thrown into shadow
user: the idea had come to her to write ‘a kind of woman's destiny’ set between 1940 and 1986. It would be something like Maupaussant's A Life and convey the passage of time inside and outside of herself."  Later she describes the inseparability of the book from her life as

this was a perfect book. i dont actually wanna read anything but annie ernaux right now. it was so good and beautiful. its literally everything - a whole entire life. and what a way to tell the story of a woman’s life: here are the things that happened, here’s how we lived, here’s our history and every once in a while, here’s how i felt about it. honestly, the “here’s how i felt about it” parts are my favorite. i love the way she can bring about past feelings and look at them with clarity and kindness but without creating too much meaning from them. i dont know that ive ever felt more seen/related to something more than her writing. also makes me want to write again (and write like her). all in all, i feel like a much more complete person after reading the years.
